verses.textEn: And so, they, because of my pretense and for the sake of a brief time of a corruptible life, would be misled, and, through this stain and desecration, I would defile my last years.
verses.textLa: et ipsi propter meam simulationem, et propter modicum corruptibilis vitæ tempus decipiantur, et per hoc maculam, atque execrationem meæ senectuti conquiram.

verses.textEn: But if, in the present time, I were rescued from the torments of men, I would then not escape the hand of the Almighty, neither in life, nor in death.
verses.textLa: Nam, etsi in præsenti tempore suppliciis hominum eripiar, sed manum Omnipotentis nec vivus, nec defunctus effugiam.

verses.textEn: For this reason, by departing life with fortitude, I will show myself to be clearly worthy of my long life.
verses.textLa: Quam ob rem fortiter vita excedendo, senectute quidem dignus apparebo:

verses.textEn: And so, I will bequeath an example of fortitude to youths, if, with a ready soul and constancy, I carry out an honest death, for the sake of the most serious and most holy laws.” And having said this, he was immediately dragged away to execution.
verses.textLa: adolescentibus autem exemplum forte relinquam, si prompto animo, ac fortiter pro gravissimis ac sanctissimis legibus honesta morte perfungar. His dictis, confestim ad supplicium trahebatur.

verses.textEn: But those who led him, and who were more mild a little before, were turned to anger because of the words spoken by him, which they considered to have been brought forth by way of arrogance.
verses.textLa: Hi autem, qui eum ducebant, et paulo ante fuerant mitiores, in iram conversi sunt propter sermones ab eo dictos, quos illi per arrogantiam prolatos arbitrabantur.

verses.textEn: But when he was ready to perish by the scourges, he groaned, and he said: “O Lord, who holds all holy knowledge, you clearly understand that, although I could be freed from death, I suffer grievous pains in body. Truly, according to the soul, I willingly endure these things, because of your fear.”
verses.textLa: Sed, cum plagis perimeretur, ingemuit, et dixit: Domine, qui habes sanctam scientiam, manifeste tu scis, quia, cum a morte possem liberari, duros corporis sustineo dolores: secundum animam vero propter timorem tuum libenter hæc patior.

verses.textEn: And the way in which this man passed from this life, bequeathed, not only to youths, but also to the entire people, the memory of his death as an example of virtue and fortitude.
verses.textLa: Et iste quidem hoc modo vita decessit, non solum iuvenibus, sed et universæ genti memoriam mortis suæ ad exemplum virtutis et fortitudinis derelinquens.

verses.textEn: And it happened also that seven brothers, united with their mother, were apprehended and compelled by the king to eat the flesh of swine against divine law, being tormented with scourges and whips.
verses.textLa: Contigit autem et septem fratres una cum matre sua apprehensos compelli a rege edere contra fas carnes porcinas, flagris, et taureis cruciatos.
verses.notes:
The seven brothers united under one mother are a figure of the seven parts of the one Catholic Church, with the mother representing the Virgin Mary. (The Church will be restructured to have seven parts in the early 2020’s.)
 Two different kinds of whips are indicated here: ‘flagris, et taureis.’

verses.textEn: But one of them, who was first, spoke in this way: “What would you ask, or what would you want to learn from us? We are ready to die, rather than to betray the laws that our fathers received from God.”
verses.textLa: Unus autem ex illis, qui erat primus, sic ait: Quid quæris, et quid vis discere a nobis? parati sumus mori, magis, quam patrias Dei leges prævaricari.

verses.textEn: And so the king, being angry, ordered frying pans and bronze caldrons to be heated. When these were presently heated,
verses.textLa: Iratus itaque rex iussit sartagines, et ollas æneas succendi: quibus statim succensis,
verses.notes: The word ‘statim’ does not always mean ‘immediately,’ it can also refer to an action that is ‘now’ or ‘presently’ completed, but which may have taken some time to occur.

verses.textEn: he ordered the tongue of him who had spoken first to be cut off, and, once the skin of his head had been pulled off, likewise his hands and feet to be cut off at the top, while the rest of his brothers and his mother were watching.
verses.textLa: iussit, ei, qui prior fuerat locutus, amputari linguam: et, cute capitis abstracta, summas quoque manus et pedes ei præscindi, ceteris eius fratribus, et matre inspicientibus.
verses.notes: His hands and feet were cut off at the top, meaning at the wrist and ankles.

verses.textEn: And when now he had been made helpless in all parts, he commanded him to be moved to the fire, and, while still breathing, to be fried in the frying pan. As he was suffering long torments therein, the rest, united with the mother, exhorted one another to die with fortitude,
verses.textLa: Et, cum iam per omnia inutilis factus esset, iussit ignem admoveri, et adhuc spirantem torreri in sartagine: in qua cum diu cruciaretur, ceteri una cum matre invicem se hortabantur mori fortiter,

verses.textEn: saying: “The Lord God will perceive the truth, and he will be consoled in us, in the way that Moses declared in the profession of the canticle: ‘And in his servants, he will be consoled.’ ”
verses.textLa: dicentes: Dominus Deus aspiciet veritatem, et consolabitur in nobis, quemadmodum in protestatione cantici declaravit Moyses: Et in servis suis consolabitur.
verses.notes: Yes, it actually says that God will be consoled, rather than saying that we will be consoled.

verses.textEn: And so, when the first had died in this way, they led in the next one, so as to ridicule him. And when the skin of his head was pulled off with the hair, they asked him if he would eat, instead of being punished throughout the whole body in every limb.
verses.textLa: Mortuo itaque illo primo, hoc modo, sequentem deducebant ad illudendum: et, cute capitis eius cum capillis abstracta, interrogabant, si manducaret prius, quam toto corpore per membra singula puniretur.

verses.textEn: But responding in the language of his fathers, he said, “I will not do it.” Because of this, he also, in the next place, received the torments of the first.
verses.textLa: At ille, respondens patria voce, dixit: Non faciam. Propter quod et iste, sequenti loco, primi tormenta suscepit:
verses.notes: The language of his fathers was Hebrew. This language choice is specified because, at that time, the spoken language of the Jews was Aramaic. Yet they would speak in Hebrew when it was an important question of religion.

verses.textEn: And when he had reached his last breath, he spoke in this way: “You, indeed, O most wicked man, are destroying us in this present life. But the King of the world will raise us up, in eternal life at the resurrection, for we die on behalf of his laws.”
verses.textLa: et in ultimo spiritu constitutus, sic ait: Tu quidem scelestissime in præsenti vita nos perdis: sed Rex mundi defunctos nos pro suis legibus in æternæ vitæ resurrectione suscitabit.

verses.textEn: After this one, the third was ridiculed, and when he was asked, he quickly offered up his tongue, and he resolutely extended his hands.
verses.textLa: Post hunc tertius illuditur, et linguam postulatus cito protulit, et manus constanter extendit:

verses.textEn: And he said with confidence, “I possess these from heaven, but, because of the laws of God, I now despise them, for I hope to receive them again from him.”
verses.textLa: et cum fiducia ait: E cælo ista possideo, sed propter Dei leges nunc hæc ipsa despicio, quoniam ab ipso me ea recepturum spero:

verses.textEn: So then, the king and those who were with him, wondered at the soul of this youth, because he considered the torments as if they were nothing.
verses.textLa: ita ut rex, et qui cum ipso erant, mirarentur adolescentis animum, quod tamquam nihilum duceret cruciatus.

verses.textEn: And after he had died in this way, they afflicted the fourth with similar tortures.
verses.textLa: Et hoc ita defuncto, quartum vexabant similiter torquentes.

verses.textEn: And when he was about to die, he spoke in this way: “It is preferable, being put to death by men, to wait for hope from God, so as to be revived again by him. But the resurrection to life will not be for you.
verses.textLa: Et, cum iam esset ad mortem, sic ait: Potius est ab hominibus morti datos spem expectare a Deo, iterum ab ipso resuscitandos: tibi enim resurrectio ad vitam non erit.

verses.textEn: And when they had brought the fifth, they afflicted him. But he, gazing at him,
verses.textLa: Et cum admovissent quintum, vexabant eum. At ille, respiciens in eum,

verses.textEn: said: “Having power among men, though you are corruptible, you do what you want, but do not think that our nation has been abandoned by God.
verses.textLa: dixit: Potestatem inter homines habens, cum sis corruptibilis, facis quod vis: noli autem putare genus nostrum a Deo esse derelictum.

verses.textEn: And so, wait patiently for a while, and you will see his great power, by the manner in which he will torture you and your offspring.”
verses.textLa: Tu autem patienter sustine, et videbis magnam potestatem ipsius, qualiter te, et semen tuum torquebit.

verses.textEn: After this one, they brought the sixth, and he, being about to die, spoke in this way: “Do not go astray in vain. For we suffer because of ourselves, having sinned against our God, yet things worthy of admiration have been accomplished in us.
verses.textLa: Post hunc ducebant sextum, et is, mori incipiens, sic ait: Noli frustra errare: nos enim propter nosmetipsos hæc patimur, peccantes in Deum nostrum, et digna admiratione facta sunt in nobis:

verses.textEn: But do not consider that you will be without punishment, for you have attempted to fight against God.”
verses.textLa: tu autem ne existimes tibi impune futurum, quod contra Deum pugnare tentaveris.

verses.textEn: Now the mother was wonderful beyond measure, and a worthy memorial of the good, for she watched her seven sons perish within the time of one day, and she bore it with a good soul, because of the hope that she had in God.
verses.textLa: Supra modum autem mater mirabilis, et bonorum memoria digna, quæ pereuntes septem filios sub unius diei tempore conspiciens, bono animo ferebat propter spem, quam in Deum habebat:

verses.textEn: And, with fortitude, she exhorted every one of them, in the language of the fathers, being filled with wisdom. And, joining masculine courage with feminine thinking,
verses.textLa: singulos illorum hortabatur voce patria fortiter, repleta sapientia: et, femineæ cogitationi masculinum animum inserens,

verses.textEn: she said to them: “I do not know how you were formed in my womb. For I did not give you spirit, nor soul, nor life; neither did I construct each of your limbs.
verses.textLa: dixit ad eos: Nescio qualiter in utero meo apparuistis: neque enim ego spiritum et animam donavi vobis et vitam, et singulorum membra non ego ipsa compegi,

verses.textEn: Nevertheless, the Creator of the world, who formed the nativity of man, and who founded the origins of all, will restore both spirit and life to you again, with his mercy, just as you now despise yourselves for the sake of his laws.”
verses.textLa: sed enim mundi Creator, qui formavit hominis nativitatem, quique omnium invenit originem, et spiritum vobis iterum cum misericordia reddet et vitam, sicut nunc vosmetipsos despicitis propter leges eius.

verses.textEn: But Antiochus, thinking himself despised, and at the same time also despising the voice of the reproacher, when only the youngest was still left, not only exhorted him with words, but also assured him with an oath, that he would make him wealthy and happy, and, if he would convert from the laws of his fathers, he would have him as a friend, and he would provide him with necessary things.
verses.textLa: Antiochus autem, contemni se arbitratus, simul et exprobrantis voce despecta, cum adhuc adolescentior superesset, non solum verbis hortabatur, sed et cum iuramento affirmabat se divitem et beatum facturum, et translatum a patriis legibus amicum habiturum, et res necessarias ei præbiturum.

verses.textEn: But, when the youth was not swayed by these things, the king called the mother and persuaded her to act toward the youth to save him.
verses.textLa: Sed ad hæc cum adolescens nequaquam inclinaretur, vocavit rex matrem, et suadebat ei ut adolescenti fieret in salutem.

verses.textEn: And so, when he had exhorted her with many words, she promised that she would counsel her son.
verses.textLa: Cum autem multis eam verbis esset hortatus, promisit suasurum se filio suo.

verses.textEn: Then, leaning towards him and mocking the cruel tyrant, she said in the language of the fathers: “My son, take pity on me, for I carried you for nine months in my womb, and I gave you milk for three years, and I nourished you and led you through to this stage of life.
verses.textLa: Itaque inclinata ad illum, irridens crudelem tyrannum, ait patria voce: Fili mi, miserere mei, quæ te in utero novem mensibus portavi, et lac triennio dedi et alui, et in ætatem istam perduxi.
verses.notes: The Jews in ancient times counted any partial calendar year as a year. So, three years of breast-feeding is not 36 months; rather it is part of one calendar year, all of the next calendar year, and part of the subsequent calendar year, amounting to as little as 14 months.

verses.textEn: I ask you, child, gaze upon heaven and earth, and all that is in them, and understand that God made them, and the family of man, out of nothing.
verses.textLa: Peto, nate, ut aspicias ad cælum et terram, et ad omnia quæ in eis sunt: et intelligas, quia ex nihilo fecit illa Deus, et hominum genus:

verses.textEn: So shall it be that you will not fear this executioner, but, participating worthily with your brothers, you shall accept death, so that, by this mercy, I shall receive you again with your brothers.”
verses.textLa: ita fiet, ut non timeas carnificem istum, sed dignus fratribus tuis effectus particeps, suscipe mortem, ut in illa miseratione cum fratribus tuis te recipiam.

verses.textEn: While she was still saying these things, the youth said: “What are you waiting for? I will not obey the precepts of the king, but the precepts of the law, which was given to us through Moses.
verses.textLa: Cum hæc illa adhuc diceret, ait adolescens: Quem sustinetis? non obedio præcepto regis, sed præcepto legis, quæ data est nobis per Moysen.

verses.textEn: In truth, you, who have been the inventor of all malice against the Hebrews, will not escape the hand of God.
verses.textLa: Tu vero, qui inventor omnis malitiæ factus es in Hebræos, non effugies manum Dei.

verses.textEn: For we suffer these things because of our sins.
verses.textLa: Nos enim pro peccatis nostris hæc patimur.

verses.textEn: And if, for the sake of our chastisement and correction, the Lord our God is angry with us for a little while, yet still he will be reconciled again to his servants.
verses.textLa: Et si nobis propter increpationem, et correptionem Dominus Deus noster modicum iratus est: sed iterum reconciliabitur servis suis.

verses.textEn: But as for you, O wicked and most disgraceful of all men, do be not be extolled over nothing, with vain hopes, while you are inflamed against his servants.
verses.textLa: Tu autem, o sceleste, et omnium hominum flagitiosissime, noli frustra extolli vanis spebus in servos eius inflammatus.

verses.textEn: For you have not yet escaped the judgment of Almighty God, who examines all things.
verses.textLa: Nondum enim omnipotentis Dei, et omnia inspicientis, iudicium effugisti.

verses.textEn: Therefore, my brothers, having now sustained brief sorrow, have been brought under the covenant of eternal life. But, in truth, you, by the judgment of God, will be released into just punishment for your arrogance.
verses.textLa: Nam fratres mei, modico nunc dolore sustentato, sub testamento æternæ vitæ effecti sunt: tu vero iudicio Dei iustas superbiæ tuæ pœnas exolves.

verses.textEn: But I, like my brothers, deliver up my soul and my body for the sake of the laws of the fathers, calling upon God so as to bring forgiveness upon our nation sooner, and so that you, with torments and lashings, may confess that he alone is God.
verses.textLa: Ego autem, sicut fratres mei, animam, et corpus meum trado pro patriis legibus: invocans Deum maturius genti nostræ propitium fieri, teque cum tormentis et verberibus confiteri quod ipse est Deus solus.
verses.notes: The word ‘maturius’ refers to an earlier maturity.

verses.textEn: Truly, in me and in my brothers, the wrath of the Almighty, which has been led over all our people justly, shall cease.”
verses.textLa: In me vero et in fratribus meis desinet Omnipotentis ira, quæ super omne genus nostrum iuste superducta est.

verses.textEn: Then the king, burning with anger, raged against this one with cruelty beyond all the rest, bearing it indignantly that he himself was derided.
verses.textLa: Tunc rex accensus ira in hunc super omnes crudelius desævit, indigne ferens se derisum.

verses.textEn: And so this one also died in purity, trusting in the Lord through all things.
verses.textLa: Et hic itaque mundus obiit, per omnia in Domino confidens.

verses.textEn: Then, last of all, after the sons, the mother also was consumed.
verses.textLa: Novissime autem post filios et mater consumpta est.

verses.textEn: Therefore, about the sacrifices and about the exceedingly great cruelties, enough has been said.
verses.textLa: Igitur de sacrificiis, et de nimiis crudelitatibus satis dictum est.

verses.textEn: In truth, Judas Maccabeus, and those who were with him, went secretly into the villages, and, calling together their relatives and friends, and accepting among them those who persevered in Judaism, they brought six thousand men together.
verses.textLa: Iudas vero Machabæus, et qui cum illo erant, introibant latenter in castella: et convocantes cognatos, et amicos, et eos, qui permanserunt in Iudaismo, assumentes, eduxerunt ad se sex millia virorum.

verses.textEn: And they called upon the Lord: to look upon his people, who were downtrodden by all; and to take pity on the temple, which was defiled by the impious;
verses.textLa: Et invocabant Dominum, ut respiceret in populum, qui ab omnibus calcabatur: et misereretur templo, quod contaminabatur ab impiis:

verses.textEn: and even to take pity on the city by utter destruction, for it was willing to be immediately leveled to the ground; and to hear the voice of the blood that was crying out to him,
verses.textLa: misereretur etiam exterminio civitatis, quæ esset illico complananda, et vocem sanguinis ad se clamantis audiret:
verses.notes: In other words, they even asked God to utterly destroy the city, and everyone in it, rather than to let these sacrileges and blasphemies continue. It was not the case that the city was going to be destroyed by the Gentiles; they were using the city, profanely, but had no intention of destroying it.

verses.textEn: so that he would remember also the most iniquitous deaths of the innocent little ones, and the blasphemies brought upon his name; and to show his indignation over these things.
verses.textLa: memoraretur quoque iniquissimas mortes parvulorum innocentum, et blasphemias nomini suo illatas, et indignaretur super his.

verses.textEn: And so Maccabeus, having gathered together a multitude, could not be withstood by the Gentiles. For the wrath of the Lord had turned into mercy.
verses.textLa: At Machabæus, congregata multitudine, intolerabilis Gentibus efficiebatur: ira enim Domini in misericordiam conversa est.

verses.textEn: And so, overwhelming the towns and cities unexpectedly, he set them on fire. And, occupying strategic positions, he made no small slaughter of the enemies.
verses.textLa: Et superveniens castellis, et civitatibus improvisus, succendebat eas: et opportuna loca occupans, non paucas hostium strages dabat:

verses.textEn: Moreover, especially in the nights, he carried out expeditions in this way. And the fame of his virtuous strength was spread abroad everywhere.
verses.textLa: maxime autem noctibus ad huiuscemodi excursus ferebatur, et fama virtutis eius ubique diffundebatur.
verses.notes: The meaning of ‘virtutis’ here is really something like ‘virtuous strength.’ One would not describe even a successful enemy of Israel as ‘virtutis.’

verses.textEn: Then Philip, seeing that the man gained ground little by little, and that things frequently fell out in his favor, wrote to Ptolemy, governor of Coelesyria and Phoenicia, to send auxiliaries to carry out the work of the king.
verses.textLa: Videns autem Philippus paulatim virum ad profectum venire, ac frequentius res ei cedere propere, ad Ptolemæum ducem Cœlesyriæ, et Phœnicis scripsit ut auxilium ferret regis negotiis.

verses.textEn: And so, he quickly sent Nicanor, son of Patroclus, from his foremost friends, providing him with no less than twenty thousand armed men from throughout the Gentiles, to wipe out the entire race of the Jews, joining with him Gorgias, a military man with very great experience in the things of warfare.
verses.textLa: At ille velociter misit Nicanorem Patrocli de primoribus amicum, datis ei de permistis Gentibus, armatis non minus viginti millibus, ut universum Iudæorum genus deleret, adiuncto ei Gorgia viro militari, et in bellicis rebus experientissimo.

verses.textEn: Moreover, Nicanor decided to raise a tribute for the king of two thousand talents, which was to be given to the Romans, and which would be supplied by means of the captivity of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Constituit autem Nicanor, ut regi tributum, quod Romanis erat dandum, duo millia talentorum de captivitate Iudæorum suppleret:

verses.textEn: And immediately he sent to the maritime cities, calling them to the auction of the Jewish slaves, promising them a parcel of ninety slaves for one talent, not reflecting on the vengeance which would befall him subsequently from the Almighty.
verses.textLa: statimque ad maritimas civitates misit, convocans ad coemptionem Iudaicorum mancipiorum, promittens se nonaginta mancipia talento distracturum, non respiciens ad vindictam, quæ eum ab Omnipotente esset consecutura.
verses.notes: The maritime cities, being ports, would all be centers of commerce and trading. So the Jews were to be sold in lots to these men, wholesale, to be resold later individually or in smaller groups.

verses.textEn: Then, when Judas learned that Nicanor was approaching, he revealed it to those Jews who were with him.
verses.textLa: Iudas autem ubi comperit, indicavit his, qui secum erant, Iudæis Nicanoris adventum.

verses.textEn: And certain ones among them, being afraid and not trusting in the justice of God, turned and fled away.
verses.textLa: Ex quibus quidam formidantes, et non credentes Dei iustitiæ, in fugam vertebantur:

verses.textEn: In truth, others sold all that was in excess, and together beseeched the Lord, that he would rescue them from the impious Nicanor, who had sold them before he even came near them,
verses.textLa: alii vero si quid eis supererat vendebant, simulque Dominum deprecabantur ut eriperet eos ab impio Nicanore, qui eos prius quam cominus veniret, vendiderat:

verses.textEn: and if not for their sakes, then for the sake of the covenant which was made with their fathers, and for the sake of the invocation of his holy and magnificent name over them.
verses.textLa: et si non propter eos, propter testamentum tamen quod erat ad patres eorum, et propter invocationem sancti et magnifici nominis eius super ipsos.

verses.textEn: But Maccabeus, calling together seven thousand who were with him, asked them not to be reconciled to the enemies, and not to fear the multitude of the enemies who came against them unjustly, but to struggle with fortitude,
verses.textLa: Convocatis autem Machabæus septem millibus, qui cum ipso erant, rogabat ne hostibus reconciliarentur, neque metuerent inique venientium adversum se hostium multitudinem, sed fortiter contenderent,

verses.textEn: holding before their eyes the contempt that had been brought upon the holy place by them, and likewise also the mockery which they held to the injury of the city, even to the extent of overthrowing the institutions of old.
verses.textLa: ante oculos habentes contumeliam, quæ loco sancto ab his iniuste esset illata, itemque et ludibrio habitæ civitatis iniuriam, adhuc etiam veterum instituta convulsa.

verses.textEn: For he said that these, indeed, trust in their weapons, as well as in their boldness; but we trust in the Almighty Lord, who is able to wipe out both those coming against us, and even the whole world, with one nod.
verses.textLa: Nam illi quidem armis confidunt, ait, simul et audacia: nos autem in omnipotente Domino, qui potest et venientes adversum nos, et universum mundum uno nutu delere, confidimus.

verses.textEn: Moreover, he reminded them also of the assistance of God which their parents had received; and how, under Sennacherib, one hundred and eighty-five thousand had perished;
verses.textLa: Admonuit autem eos et de auxiliis Dei, quæ facta sunt erga parentes: et quod sub Sennacherib centum octoginta quinque millia perierunt:

verses.textEn: and of the battle by them, which was against the Galatians in Babylonia, how, when the event had arrived and the allies of the Macedonians hesitated, though they were only six thousand in all, yet they slew one hundred and twenty thousand, because of the help provided to them from heaven; and how, for the sake of these things, very many benefits followed.
verses.textLa: et de prælio, quod eis adversus Galatas fuit in Babylonia, ut omnes, ubi ad rem ventum est, Macedonibus sociis hæsitantibus, ipsi sex millia soli peremerunt centum viginti millia propter auxilium illis datum de cælo, et beneficia pro his plurima consecuti sunt.

verses.textEn: By these words, they were brought to constancy and were prepared to die for the laws and their nation.
verses.textLa: His verbis constantes effecti sunt, et pro legibus, et patria mori parati.

verses.textEn: And so, he appointed his brothers as leaders over each division: Simon, and Joseph, and Jonathan, subjecting one thousand and five hundred men to each of them.
verses.textLa: Constituit itaque fratres suos duces utrique ordini, Simonem, et Iosephum, et Ionathan, subiectis unicuique millenis et quingentenis.

verses.textEn: And at that point, the holy book having been read to them by Esdras, and having given them a sign of the assistance of God, with himself leading the first point, he joined battle with Nicanor.
verses.textLa: Ad hoc etiam ab Esdra lecto illis sancto libro, et dato signo adiutorii Dei, in prima acie ipse dux commisit cum Nicanore.

verses.textEn: And, with the Almighty as their helper, they slew over nine thousand men. Furthermore, having wounded and disabled the greater part of the army of Nicanor, they forced them to take flight.
verses.textLa: Et facto sibi adiutore Omnipotente, interfecerunt super novem millia hominum: maiorem autem partem exercitus Nicanoris vulneribus debilem factam fugere compulerunt.

verses.textEn: In fact, they took away the money from those who came to buy them, and they pursued them everywhere.
verses.textLa: Pecuniis vero eorum, qui ad emptionem ipsorum venerant, sublatis, ipsos usquequaque persecuti sunt,

verses.textEn: But they turned back at the close of the hour, for it was before the Sabbath. For this reason, they did not continue the pursuit.
verses.textLa: sed reversi sunt hora conclusi: nam erat ante Sabbatum: quam ob causam non perseveraverunt insequentes.

verses.textEn: But, having gathered together their weapons and spoils, they kept the Sabbath, blessing the Lord who had delivered them in that day, showering the beginning of mercy on them.
verses.textLa: Arma autem ipsorum, et spolia congregantes, Sabbatum agebant: benedicentes Dominum, qui liberavit eos in isto die, misericordiæ initium stillans in eos.

verses.textEn: In truth, after the Sabbath, they divided the spoils to the disabled, and the orphans, and the widows, and the remainder they kept for themselves and their own.
verses.textLa: Post Sabbatum vero debilibus, et orphanis, et viduis diviserunt spolia: et residua ipsi cum suis habuere.

verses.textEn: And so, when these things were done, and supplication was made by all in common, they asked the merciful Lord to be reconciled to his servants unto the end.
verses.textLa: His itaque gestis, et communiter ab omnibus facta obsecratione, misericordem Dominum postulabant, ut in finem servis suis reconciliaretur.

verses.textEn: And, among those who were fighting against them with Timothy and Bacchides, they slew more than twenty thousand, and they obtained the high fortresses, and they divided many spoils, making equal portions for the disabled, the fatherless, and the widows, and even the aged.
verses.textLa: Et ex his, qui cum Timotheo, et Bacchide erant contra se contendentes, super viginti millia interfecerunt, et munitiones excelsas obtinuerunt: et plures prædas diviserunt, æquam portionem debilibus, pupillis, et viduis, sed et senioribus facientes.

verses.textEn: And when they had carefully collected their weapons, they stored them all in strategic places, and, in truth, the remainder of the spoils they carried to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et cum arma eorum diligenter collegissent, omnia composuerunt in locis opportunis, residua vero spolia Ierosolymam detulerunt:

verses.textEn: And they put to death Philarches, a wicked man, who was with Timothy, who had brought many afflictions upon the Jews.
verses.textLa: et Philarchen, qui cum Timotheo erat, interfecerunt, virum scelestum, qui in multis Iudæos afflixerat.

verses.textEn: And when they celebrated the song of victory at Jerusalem, they burned him who had set fire to the sacred doors, that is, Callisthenes, when he had taken refuge in a certain house, repaying him a worthy reward for his impieties.
verses.textLa: Et cum epinicia agerent Ierosolymis, eum, qui sacras ianuas incenderat, id est, Callisthenem, cum in quoddam domicilium refugisset, incenderunt, digna ei mercede pro impietatibus suis reddita.

verses.textEn: But as for that most vicious Nicanor, who had led in a thousand merchants for the sale of the Jews,
verses.textLa: Facinorosissimus autem Nicanor, qui mille negotiantes ad Iudæorum venditionem adduxerat,

verses.textEn: he was brought low with the help of the Lord, and by those whom he considered to be worthless. Putting aside the glorious vestments, fleeing by an inland route, he arrived alone at Antioch, having been brought to the greatest unhappiness by the destruction of his army.
verses.textLa: humiliatus auxilio Domini ab his, quos nullos existimaverat, deposita veste gloriæ, per mediterranea fugiens, solus venit Antiochiam, summam infelicitatem de interitu sui exercitus consecutus.

verses.textEn: And he who had promised to pay a tribute to the Romans from the captives of Jerusalem, now professed that the Jews had God as their protector, and, for this reason, they were invulnerable, because they followed the laws established by him.
verses.textLa: Et qui promiserat Romanis se tributum restituere de captivitate Ierosolymorum, prædicabat nunc protectorem Deum habere Iudæos, et ob ipsum invulnerabiles esse, eo quod sequerentur leges ab ipso constitutas.

verses.textEn: At the same time, Antiochus returned in dishonor from Persia.
verses.textLa: Eodem tempore Antiochus inhoneste revertebatur de Perside.

verses.textEn: For he had entered into the city called Persepolis, and attempted to rob the temple, and to oppress the city, but the multitude, rushing to arms, turned them to flight, and so it happened that Antiochus, after fleeing, returned in disgrace.
verses.textLa: Intraverat enim in eam, quæ dicitur Persepolis, et tentavit expoliare templum, et civitatem opprimere: sed multitudine ad arma concurrente, in fugam versi sunt: et ita contigit ut Antiochus post fugam turpiter rediret.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived near Ecbatana, he realized what had happened to Nicanor and Timothy.
verses.textLa: Et cum venisset circa Ecbatanam, recognovit quæ erga Nicanorem, et Timotheum gesta sunt.

verses.textEn: And so, rising up in anger, he thought to turn back upon the Jews the injury done by those who had put him to flight. And, therefore, he ordered his chariot to be driven without stopping along the way, for the judgment of heaven was urging him on, because he had spoken so arrogantly about how he would come to Jerusalem and make it into a mass grave for the Jews.
verses.textLa: Elatus autem in ira, arbitrabatur se iniuriam illorum, qui se fugaverant, posse in Iudæos retorquere: ideoque iussit agitari currum suum, sine intermissione agens iter, cælesti eum iudicio perurgente, eo quod ita superbe locutus est se venturum Ierosolymam, et congeriem sepulchri Iudæorum eam facturum.

verses.textEn: But the Lord God of Israel, who oversees all things, struck him with an incurable and invisible plague. For, as soon as he had finished these words, a dire pain in his abdomen seized him, with bitter internal torments.
verses.textLa: Sed qui universa conspicit Dominus Deus Israel, percussit eum insanabili, et invisibili plaga. Ut enim finivit hunc ipsum sermonem, apprehendit eum dolor dirus viscerum, et amara internorum tormenta:

verses.textEn: And, indeed, it sprung forth justly, since he had tormented the internal organs of others with many strange and new tortures, yet he in no way ceased from his malice.
verses.textLa: et quidem satis iuste, quippe qui multis, et novis cruciatibus aliorum torserat viscera, licet ille nullo modo a sua malitia cessaret.

verses.textEn: But, beyond this, being filled with arrogance, breathing fire with his soul against the Jews, and instructing the task to be accelerated, it happened that, as he was rushing on forcefully, he fell from the chariot, and his limbs were afflicted with a serious bruising of the body.
verses.textLa: Super hoc autem superbia repletus, ignem spirans animo in Iudæos, et præcipiens accelerari negotium, contigit illum impetu euntem de curru cadere, et gravi corporis collisione membra vexari.

verses.textEn: And he, being filled with arrogance beyond human means, seemed to himself to command even the waves of the sea and to weigh even the heights of the mountains in a balance. But now, humbled to the ground, he was carried on a stretcher, calling himself as a witness to the manifest virtue of God.
verses.textLa: Isque qui sibi videbatur etiam fluctibus maris imperare, supra humanum modum superbia repletus, et montium altitudines in statera appendere, nunc humiliatus ad terram in gestatorio portabatur, manifestam Dei virtutem in semetipso contestans:
verses.notes: The phrase ‘in semetipso contestans’ means ‘calling himself as a witness;’ the verb refers to calling a witness, but in this case before God, the witness is himself and his own misfortune.

verses.textEn: So then, worms swarmed from his impious body, and, as he lived on in pain, his flesh fell away, and then his odorous stench oppressed the army.
verses.textLa: ita ut de corpore impii vermes scaturirent, ac viventis in doloribus carnes eius effluerent, odore etiam illius et fœtore exercitus gravaretur.

verses.textEn: And him who, a little before, thought that he could touch the stars of heaven, no one could endure to carry, because of the intolerable stench.
verses.textLa: Et qui paulo ante sidera cæli contingere se arbitrabatur, eum nemo poterat propter intolerantiam fœtoris portare.

verses.textEn: And so, from then on, being led away from his heavy arrogance by the admonishment of a divine plague, he began to come to an understanding of himself, with his pains increasing through every moment.
verses.textLa: Hinc igitur cœpit ex gravi superbia deductus ad agnitionem sui venire, divina admonitus plaga, per momenta singula doloribus suis augmenta capientibus.

verses.textEn: And, when he could not even bear his own stench, he spoke in this way: “It is just to be subject to God, and a mortal should not consider himself equal to God.”
verses.textLa: Et cum nec ipse iam fœtorem suum ferre posset, ita ait: Iustum est subditum esse Deo, et mortalem non paria Deo sentire.

verses.textEn: Then this wicked one prayed to the Lord, from whom, subsequently, there might be no mercy.
verses.textLa: Orabat autem hic scelestus Dominum, a quo non esset misericordiam consecuturus.
verses.notes: In other words, there would be no mercy for him, if he did not soon repent, since he was wicked and near death.

verses.textEn: And the city, to which he was going in haste to pull it down to the ground and to make it a mass grave, he now wanted to make free.
verses.textLa: Et civitatem, ad quam festinans veniebat ut eam ad solum deduceret, ac sepulchrum congestorum faceret, nunc optat liberam reddere:

verses.textEn: And the Jews, whom he had said he certainly did not consider worthy even to be buried, but would deliver them to be torn apart by birds and wild beasts, and would exterminate them with their little ones, he now promised to make equal with the Athenians.
verses.textLa: et Iudæos, quos nec sepultura quidem se dignos habiturum, sed avibus ac feris diripiendos traditurum, et cum parvulis exterminaturum dixerat, æquales nunc Atheniensibus facturum pollicetur:

verses.textEn: And even the holy temple, which before he had plundered, he would adorn with the best gifts, and increase the holy vessels, and pay out from his revenues the charges pertaining to the sacrifices.
verses.textLa: templum etiam sanctum, quod prius expoliaverat, optimis donis ornaturum, et sancta vasa multiplicaturum, et pertinentes ad sacrificia sumptus de redditibus suis præstaturum:

verses.textEn: Beyond these things, he would even become a Jew himself, and would travel through every place on earth and declare the power of God.
verses.textLa: super hæc, et Iudæum se futurum, et omnem locum terræ perambulaturum, et prædicaturum Dei potestatem.

verses.textEn: But, when his pains did not cease, (for the just judgment of God had overwhelmed him,) in despair he wrote to the Jews, in the manner of a supplication, a letter composed in this way:
verses.textLa: Sed non cessantibus doloribus (supervenerat enim in eum iustum Dei iudicium) desperans scripsit ad Iudæos in modum deprecationis epistolam hæc continentem:

verses.textEn: “To the very good citizens of the Jews, Antiochus, king and ruler, wishes much health, and welfare, and happiness.
verses.textLa: OPTIMIS civibus Iudæis plurimam salutem, et bene valere, et esse felices, rex et principes Antiochus.

verses.textEn: If you and your sons are faring well, and if everything is according to your will, we give very great thanks.
verses.textLa: Si bene valetis, et filii vestri, et ex sententia vobis cuncta sunt, maximas agimus gratias.

verses.textEn: And so, fixed in infirmity, yet kindly remembering you, I am returning from the places of Persia, and, having been seized by a serious infirmity, I considered it necessary to have a concern for the common good,
verses.textLa: Et ego in infirmitate constitutus, vestri autem memor benigne reversus de Persidis locis, et infirmitate gravi apprehensus, necessarium duxi pro communi utilitate curam habere:

verses.textEn: not despairing in myself, but having a great hope to escape the infirmity.
verses.textLa: non desperans memetipsum, sed spem multam habens effugiendi infirmitatem.

verses.textEn: Moreover, considering that my father also, during the time that he led an army into the upper regions, revealed who would take up the leadership after him,
verses.textLa: Respiciens autem quod et pater meus, quibus temporibus in locis superioribus ducebat exercitum, ostendit qui post se susciperet principatum:

verses.textEn: so that, if anything contrary should occur, or any if difficulties should be reported, those who were in the regions, knowing to whom the whole matter had been bequeathed, would not be disturbed.
verses.textLa: ut si quid contrarium accideret, aut difficile nunciaretur, scientes hi, qui in regionibus erant, cui esset rerum summa derelicta, non turbarentur.

verses.textEn: In addition to these things, considering that whichever are the nearest powers and neighbors lie in ambush for the right time and await the right event, I have designated my son, Antiochus, as king, whom I frequently commended to many of you while traveling in the upper provinces. And I have written to him what I have added below.
verses.textLa: Ad hæc, considerans de proximo potentes quosque, et vicinos temporibus insidiantes, et eventum expectantes, designavi filium meum Antiochum regem, quem sæpe recurrens in superiora regna multis vestrum commendabam: et scripsi ad eum quæ subiecta sunt.

verses.textEn: And so, I beg you and petition you, that remembering the public and private benefits, each one will continue to be faithful to me and to my son.
verses.textLa: Ora itaque vos, et peto memores beneficiorum publice et privatim, ut unusquisque conservet fidem ad me et ad filium meum.

verses.textEn: For I trust that he will behave with moderation and humanity, and that, following my intentions, he will be impartial to you.”
verses.textLa: Confido enim, eum modeste et humane acturum, et sequentem propositum meum, et communem vobis fore.

verses.textEn: And so the murderer and blasphemer, having been struck very badly, just as he himself had treated others, passed from this life in a miserable death on a journey among the mountains.
verses.textLa: Igitur homicida, et blasphemus pessime percussus, et ut ipse alios tractaverat, peregre in montibus miserabili obitu vita functus est.

verses.textEn: But Philip, who was nurtured with him, carried away his body, and, fearing the son of Antiochus, went into Egypt to Ptolemy Philometor.
verses.textLa: Transferebat autem corpus Philippus collactaneus eius: qui, metuens filium Antiochi, ad Ptolemæum Philometorem in Ægyptum abiit.
verses.notes: The term ‘collactaneus’ literally refers to two infants both breast-fed by the same mother or nurse. However, in this case it may be more metaphorical, i.e. that they were raised together.

verses.textEn: But Maccabeus and those who were with him, the Lord protecting them, even recovered the temple and the city.
verses.textLa: Machabæus autem, et qui cum eo erant, Domino se protegente, templum quidem, et civitatem recepit:

verses.textEn: Then he demolished the altars, which the foreigners had constructed in the streets, and likewise the shrines.
verses.textLa: aras autem, quas alienigenæ per plateas extruxerant, itemque delubra demolitus est.

verses.textEn: And, having purged the temple, they made another altar. And, taking glowing stones from the fire, they began to offer sacrifices again after two years, and they set out incense, and lamps, and the bread of the Presence.
verses.textLa: Et purgato templo, aliud altare fecerunt: et de ignitis lapidibus igne concepto sacrificia obtulerunt post biennium, et incensum, et lucernas, et panes propositionis posuerunt.

verses.textEn: Having done these things, they petitioned the Lord, lying prostrate on the ground, lest they should fall once more into such evils, but also, if they should at any time sin, that they might be chastised by him more mildly, and not be delivered over to barbarians and blasphemous men.
verses.textLa: Quibus gestis, rogabant Dominum prostrati in terram, ne amplius talibus malis inciderent: sed et, si quando peccassent, ut ab ipso mitius corriperentur, et non barbaris, ac blasphemis hominibus traderentur.

verses.textEn: Then, on the day that the temple had been polluted by the foreigners, it happened on the same day that the purification was accomplished, on the twenty-fifth day of the month, which was Kislev.
verses.textLa: Qua die autem templum ab alienigenis pollutum fuerat, contigit eadem die purificationem fieri, vigesima quinta mensis, qui fuit Casleu.

verses.textEn: And they celebrated for eight days with joy, in the manner of the Feast of Tabernacles, remembering that, a little time before, they had celebrated the solemn days of the Feast of Tabernacles in mountains and caves, in the manner of wild beasts.
verses.textLa: Et cum lætitia diebus octo egerunt in modum tabernaculorum, recordantes quod ante modicum temporis diem sollemnem tabernaculorum in montibus, et in speluncis more bestiarum egerant.

verses.textEn: Because of this, they now preferred to carry boughs and green branches and palms, for him who had prospered the cleansing of his place.
verses.textLa: Propter quod thyrsos, et ramos virides, et palmas præferebant ei, qui prosperavit mundari locum suum.

verses.textEn: And they decreed a common precept and decree, that all the people of the Jews should keep those days every year.
verses.textLa: Et decreverunt communi præcepto, et decreto, universæ genti Iudæorum omnibus annis agere dies istos.

verses.textEn: Now certainly Antiochus, who was called illustrious, held himself to be so at the passing of his life.
verses.textLa: Et Antiochi quidem, qui appellatus est Nobilis, vitæ excessus ita se habuit.
verses.notes: In other words, Antiochus was called illustrious, and he thought himself to be illustrious, even unto death.

verses.textEn: But next we will describe what happened with Eupator, the son of the impious Antiochus, abridging the evils which happened in the wars.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem de Eupatore Antiochi impii filio, quæ gesta sunt narrabimus, breviantes mala, quæ in bellis gesta sunt.

verses.textEn: For when he assumed the kingdom, he appointed, over the affairs of the kingdom, a certain Lysias, leader of the Phoenician and Syrian military.
verses.textLa: Hic enim suscepto regno, constituit super negotia regni Lysiam quemdam, Phœnicis, et Syriæ militiæ principem.

verses.textEn: For Ptolemy, who was called Macer, decided to be strict in justice toward the Jews, especially because of the iniquity that had been done to them, and to deal with them peacefully.
verses.textLa: Nam Ptolemæus, qui dicebatur Macer, iusti tenax, erga Iudæos esse constituit, et præcipue propter iniquitatem, quæ facta erat in eos, et pacifice agere cum eis.

verses.textEn: But, for this reason, he was accused before Eupator by his friends, and was frequently called a traitor. For he had deserted Cyprus, which Philometor had entrusted to him. And so, transferring to Antiochus the illustrious, he even withdrew from him. And he ended his life by poison.
verses.textLa: Sed ob hoc accusatus ab amicis apud Eupatorem, cum frequenter proditor audiret, eo quod Cyprum creditam sibi a Philometore deseruisset, et ad Antiochum Nobilem translatus etiam ab eo recessisset, veneno vitam finivit.

verses.textEn: But Gorgias, when he was the leader of the places, taking to him new arrivals, frequently made war against the Jews.
verses.textLa: Gorgias autem, cum esset dux locorum, assumptis advenis frequenter Iudæos debellabat.

verses.textEn: In truth, the Jews, who held the strategic fortresses, took in those who were fleeing from Jerusalem, and they attempted to make war.
verses.textLa: Iudæi vero, qui tenebant opportunas munitiones, fugatos ab Ierosolymis suscipiebant, et bellare tentabant.

verses.textEn: In fact, those who were with Maccabeus, petitioning the Lord through prayers to be their helper, made a forceful attack upon the fortresses of the Idumeans.
verses.textLa: Hi vero, qui erant cum Machabæo, per orationes Dominum rogantes ut esset sibi adiutor, impetum fecerunt in munitiones Idumæorum:

verses.textEn: And, persevering with much force, they obtained the places, killing those they met, and cutting down in all no less than twenty thousand.
verses.textLa: multaque vi insistentes, loca obtinuerunt, occurrentes interemerunt, et omnes simul non minus viginti millibus trucidaverunt.

verses.textEn: Yet certain ones, when they had fled into two well-fortified towers, gave all appearance of fighting back.
verses.textLa: Quidam autem, cum confugissent in duas turres valde munitas, omnem apparatum ad repugnandum habentes,

verses.textEn: So Maccabeus left behind Simon and Joseph, and likewise Zachaeus, and those who were with them, to fight against them. And since those who were with them were sufficient in number, he turned back to those who attacked more forcefully.
verses.textLa: Machabæus ad eorum expugnationem, relicto Simone, et Iosepho, itemque Zachæo: eisque qui cum ipsis erant satis multis, ipse ad eas, quæ amplius perurgebant, pugnas conversus est.

verses.textEn: In truth, those who were with Simon, being led by avarice, were persuaded by money from certain ones who were in the towers. And accepting seventy thousand didrachmas, they allowed certain ones to flee.
verses.textLa: Hi vero, qui cum Simone erant, cupiditate ducti, a quibusdam, qui in turribus erant, suasi sunt pecunia: et septuaginta millibus didrachmis acceptis, dimiserunt quosdam effugere.

verses.textEn: But when what was done had been reported to Maccabeus, gathering together the leaders of the people, he accused those who had sold their brothers for money, having sent away their adversaries.
verses.textLa: Cum autem Machabæo nunciatum esset quod factum est, principibus populi congregatis, accusavit, quod pecunia fratres vendidissent, adversariis eorum dimissis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he executed these who had acted as traitors, and he quickly captured the two towers.
verses.textLa: Hos igitur proditores factos interfecit, et confestim duas turres occupavit.

verses.textEn: And so, having success in arms and in all things that he took in hand, he destroyed more than twenty thousand in the two fortresses.
verses.textLa: Armis autem ac manibus omnia prospere agendo in duabus munitionibus plus quam viginti millia peremit.

verses.textEn: And Timothy, who had been overcome by the Jews before, calling together a multitude of foreign troops and gathering horsemen from Asia, arrived as if he would capture Judea with arms.
verses.textLa: At Timotheus, qui prius a Iudæis fuerat superatus, convocato exercitu peregrinæ multitudinis, et congregato equitatu Asiano, advenit quasi armis Iudæam capturus.

verses.textEn: But Maccabeus, and those who were with him, as he was approaching, beseeched the Lord, sprinkling dirt on their heads and wrapping their waists with haircloth.
verses.textLa: Machabæus autem, et qui cum ipso erant, appropinquante illo, deprecabantur Dominum, caput terra aspergentes, lumbosque ciliciis præcincti,

verses.textEn: And lying prostrate at the pedestal of the altar, they beseeched him to be forgiving to them, but to be an enemy to their enemies, and an adversary to their adversaries, just as the law says.
verses.textLa: ad altaris crepidinem provoluti, ut sibi propitius, inimicis autem eorum esset inimicus, et adversariis adversaretur, sicut lex dicit.

verses.textEn: And so, after prayer, taking up arms, they proceeded further from the city, and, reaching close proximity to the enemies, they settled in.
verses.textLa: Et ita post orationem, sumptis armis, longius de civitate procedentes, et proximi hostibus effecti, resederunt.

verses.textEn: But, as soon as the sun rose, both sides joined battle: these ones having the guarantee of victory and success by the strength of the Lord, yet the others having courage as their leader in battle.
verses.textLa: Primo autem solis ortu utrique commiserunt: isti quidem victoriæ, et prosperitatis sponsorem cum virtute Dominum habentes: illi autem ducem belli animum habebant.

verses.textEn: But, while they were fighting vehemently, to the adversaries there appeared from heaven five men on horses, which were adorned with bridles of gold, providing leadership to the Jews.
verses.textLa: Sed, cum vehemens pugna esset, apparuerunt adversariis de cælo viri quinque in equis, frenis aureis decori, ducatum Iudæis præstantes:

verses.textEn: Two of them, having Maccabeus in the middle and surrounding him with their weapons, kept him safe. But, at the enemy, they cast darts and lightning, so that they fell down, being both confused with blindness and filled with disturbances.
verses.textLa: ex quibus duo Machabæum medium habentes, armis suis circumseptum incolumem conservabant: in adversarios autem tela, et fulmina iaciebant, ex quo et cæcitate confusi, et repleti perturbatione cadebant.

verses.textEn: Moreover, there were slain twenty thousand five hundred, along with six hundred horsemen.
verses.textLa: Interfecti sunt autem viginti millia quingenti, et equites sexcenti.

verses.textEn: In fact, Timothy fled away to Gazara, to a fortified stronghold, where Chaereas was in charge.
verses.textLa: Timotheus vero confugit in Gazaram præsidium munitum, cui præerat Chæreas.

verses.textEn: Then Maccabeus, and those who were with him, joyfully besieged the stronghold for four days.
verses.textLa: Machabæus autem, et qui cum eo erant, lætantes obsederunt præsidium diebus quatuor.

verses.textEn: But those who were inside, trusting to the strength of the place, spoke evil without limit and cast out nefarious words.
verses.textLa: At hi, qui intus erant, loci firmitate confisi, supra modum maledicebant, et sermones nefandos iactabant.

verses.textEn: But when the fifth day began to dawn, twenty youths of those who were with Maccabeus, inflamed in soul because of the blasphemy, manfully approached to the wall, and, advancing with fierce courage, ascended it.
verses.textLa: Sed cum dies quinta illucesceret, viginti iuvenes ex his, qui cum Machabæo erant, accensi animis propter blasphemiam, viriliter accesserunt ad murum, et feroci animo incedentes ascendebant:

verses.textEn: Moreover, others also getting up after them, went to set fire to the towers and the gates, and to burn the blasphemers alive.
verses.textLa: sed et alii similiter ascendentes, turres, portasque succendere aggressi sunt, atque ipsos maledicos vivos concremare.

verses.textEn: Then, having continued throughout two days to lay waste to the fortress, they killed Timothy, who was found hiding himself in a certain place. And they also killed his brother Chaereas, and Apollophanes.
verses.textLa: Per continuum autem biduum præsidio vastato, Timotheum occultantem se in quodam repertum loco peremerunt: et fratrem illius Chæream, et Apollophanem occiderunt.

verses.textEn: When this was done, they blessed the Lord with hymns and confessions, who had done great things in Israel and had given them the victory.
verses.textLa: Quibus gestis, in hymnis et confessionibus benedicebant Dominum, qui magna fecit in Israel, et victoriam dedit illis.

verses.textEn: But a short time afterwards, Lysias, the procurator of the king and a near relative, who also was in charge of the government, was heavily weighed upon by what had happened.
verses.textLa: Sed parvo post tempore, Lysias procurator regis, et propinquus, ac negotiorum præpositus, graviter ferens de his, quæ acciderant,

verses.textEn: Gathering together eight thousand, along with all the horsemen, he came against the Jews, thinking that the city would certainly be captured, making it a dwelling place for the Gentiles,
verses.textLa: congregatis octoginta millibus, et equitatu universo, veniebat adversus Iudæos, existimans se civitatem quidem captam Gentibus habitaculum facturum,

verses.textEn: in truth, also thinking to make a profit in money from the temple, just as from the other shrines of the Gentiles, and to put the priesthood up for sale every year.
verses.textLa: templum vero in pecuniæ quæstum, sicut cetera delubra Gentium, habiturum, et per singulos annos vænale sacerdotium:

verses.textEn: Never recognizing the power of God, but inflated in mind, he trusted in the multitude of the foot soldiers, and in the thousands of horsemen, and in the eighty elephants.
verses.textLa: nusquam recogitans Dei potestatem, sed mente effrenatus in multitudine peditum, et in millibus equitum, et in octoginta elephantis confidebat.

verses.textEn: And so, he entered Judea, and, approaching Bethzur, which was in a narrow place, at an interval of five stadia from Jerusalem, he laid siege to that stronghold.
verses.textLa: Ingressus autem Iudæam, et appropians Bethsuræ, quæ erat in angusto loco, ab Ierosolyma intervallo quinque stadiorum, illud præsidium expugnabat.
verses.notes: The distance of five stadia is just under one kilometer, or just under 0.6 miles.

verses.textEn: But when Maccabeus and those who were with him realized that the strongholds were besieged, they and all the crowd together petitioned the Lord with weeping and tears, that he would send a good Angel to save Israel.
verses.textLa: Ut autem Machabæus, et qui cum eo erant, cognoverunt expugnari præsidia, cum fletu et lacrymis rogabant Dominum, et omnis turba simul, ut bonum Angelum mitteret ad salutem Israel.

verses.textEn: And so the leader Maccabeus, taking up arms, exhorted the others, to undergo the peril together with him, and to bring assistance to their brothers.
verses.textLa: Et ipse primus Machabæus, sumptis armis, ceteros adhortatus est simul secum periculum subire, et ferre auxilium fratribus suis.

verses.textEn: And when they together were going forth with a ready spirit, there appeared at Jerusalem a horseman, preceding them in radiant clothing and with weapons of gold, waving a spear.
verses.textLa: Cumque pariter prompto animo procederent, Ierosolymis apparuit præcedens eos eques in veste candida, armis aureis hastam vibrans.

verses.textEn: Then they all together blessed the merciful Lord, and strengthened their souls, being prepared to break through not only men, but also the most ferocious beasts and walls of iron.
verses.textLa: Tunc omnes simul benedixerunt misericordem Dominum, et convaluerunt animis: non solum homines, sed et bestias ferocissimas, et muros ferreos parati penetrare.

verses.textEn: Thus, they went forth readily, having a helper from heaven, and with the Lord taking pity on them.
verses.textLa: Ibant igitur prompti, de cælo habentes adiutorem, et miserantem super eos Dominum.

verses.textEn: Then, rushing violently against the enemy, in the manner of lions, they struck down from among them: eleven thousand foot soldiers and one thousand six hundred horsemen.
verses.textLa: Leonum autem more impetu irruentes in hostes, prostraverunt ex eis undecim millia peditum, et equitum mille sexcentos:

verses.textEn: And they turned all the rest to flight. But many of them, being wounded, escaped with nothing. And Lysias himself also escaped, fleeing in disgrace.
verses.textLa: universos autem in fugam verterunt, plures autem ex eis vulnerati nudi evaserunt. Sed et ipse Lysias turpiter fugiens evasit.
verses.notes: The word ‘nudi’ does not mean ‘naked’ in this context; rather, it means that they escaped empty-handed, with no weapons or supplies.

verses.textEn: And because he was not irrational, thinking to himself about the loss that had happened against him, and understanding the Hebrews to be invincible because they depend upon the help of Almighty God, he sent to them,
verses.textLa: Et quia non insensatus erat, secum ipse reputans, factam erga se diminutionem, et intelligens invictos esse Hebræos, omnipotentis Dei auxilio innitentes, misit ad eos:

verses.textEn: and he promised that he would agree to all things that are just, and that he would persuade the king to be their friend.
verses.textLa: promisitque se consensurum omnibus, quæ iusta sunt, et regem compulsurum amicum fieri.

verses.textEn: Then Maccabeus assented to the request of Lysias, considering it useful in every way. And whatever Maccabeus wrote to Lysias, concerning the Jews, the king consented to it.
verses.textLa: Annuit autem Machabæus precibus Lysiæ, in omnibus utilitati consulens: et quæcumque Machabæus scripsit Lysiæ de Iudæis, ea rex concessit.

verses.textEn: For there were letters written to the Jews from Lysias, which, indeed, were composed in this way: “Lysias, to the people of the Jews: greetings.
verses.textLa: Nam erant scriptæ Iudæis epistolæ a Lysia quidem hunc modum continentes: LYSIAS populo Iudæorum salutem.

verses.textEn: John and Absalom, who had been sent from you to deliver your writings, requested that I would implement these things that were signified by them.
verses.textLa: Ioannes, et Abesalom, qui missi fuerant a vobis, tradentes scripta, postulabant ut ea, quæ per illos significabantur, implerem.

verses.textEn: Therefore, whatever things could be brought before the king, I have presented them. And he has conceded to those things that are permitted.
verses.textLa: Quæcumque igitur regi potuerunt perferri, exposui: et quæ res permittebat, concessit.

verses.textEn: If, therefore, you will keep yourselves faithful in these matters, then, from now on, I will endeavor to be a cause of your good.
verses.textLa: Si igitur in negotiis fidem conservaveritis, et deinceps bonorum vobis causa esse tentabo.

verses.textEn: But as for other particulars, I have given orders by word, both to these, and to those who have been sent by me, to confer with you.
verses.textLa: De ceteris autem per singula verbo mandavi et istis, et his, qui a me missi sunt, colloqui vobiscum.

verses.textEn: Farewell. In the one hundred forty-eighth year, on the twenty-fourth day of the month of Dioscorus.”
verses.textLa: Bene valete. Anno centesimo quadragesimo octavo mensis Dioscori, die vigesima et quarta.

verses.textEn: But the letter of the king contained this: “King Antiochus to Lysias, his brother: greetings.
verses.textLa: Regis autem epistola ista continebat: REX Antiochus Lysiæ fratri salutem.

verses.textEn: Since our father has been transferred among the gods, we are willing that those who are in our kingdom should act without tumult, and should attend diligently to their own concerns.
verses.textLa: Patre nostro inter deos translato, nos volentes eos, qui sunt in regno nostro sine tumultu agere, et rebus suis adhibere diligentiam,

verses.textEn: We have heard that the Jews would not consent to my father to convert to the rites of the Greeks, but that they chose to keep to their own institutions, and, because of this, that they ask of us to leave them to their own laws.
verses.textLa: audivimus Iudæos non consensisse patri meo ut transferrentur ad ritum Græcorum, sed tenere velle suum institutum, ac propterea postulare a nobis concedi sibi legitima sua.

verses.textEn: Therefore, wanting this nation, likewise, to be at rest, we have reached a judgment that the temple should be restored to them, so that they may act according to the custom of their ancestors.
verses.textLa: Volentes igitur hanc quoque gentem quietam esse, statuentes iudicavimus, templum restitui illis, ut agerent secundum suorum maiorum consuetudinem.

verses.textEn: You will do well, therefore, if you send to them and grant them a pledge, so that our will becomes known, and they may be of good courage, and may look after their own needs.”
verses.textLa: Bene igitur feceris, si miseris ad eos, et dexteram dederis: ut cognita nostra voluntate, bono animo sint, et utilitatibus propriis deserviant.

verses.textEn: Truly, the letter of the king to the Jews was such as this: “King Antiochus to the senate of the Jews, and to the rest of the Jews: greetings.
verses.textLa: Ad Iudæos vero regis epistola talis erat: REX Antiochus senatui Iudæorum, et ceteris Iudæis salutem.

verses.textEn: If you are well, such is what we desire. But we ourselves are also well.
verses.textLa: Si valetis, sic estis ut volumus: sed et ipsi bene valemus.

verses.textEn: Menelaus came to us, saying that you wished to come down to your own, who are among us.
verses.textLa: Adiit nos Menelaus, dicens velle vos descendere ad vestros, qui sunt apud nos.

verses.textEn: Therefore, we grant a pledge of security to those who come and go, even until the thirtieth day of the month of Xanthicus,
verses.textLa: His igitur, qui commeant usque ad diem trigesimum mensis Xanthici, damus dextras securitatis,

verses.textEn: so that the Jews may make use of their own foods and laws, just as also before, and so that none of them should endure any kind of trouble for things which have been done by ignorance.
verses.textLa: ut Iudæi utantur cibis, et legibus suis, sicut et prius: et nemo eorum ullo modo molestiam patiatur de his, quæ per ignorantiam gesta sunt.

verses.textEn: And so, we have also sent Menelaus, who will talk with you.
verses.textLa: Misimus autem et Menelaum, qui vos alloquatur.

verses.textEn: Farewell. In the one hundred forty-eighth year, on the fifteenth day of the month of Xanthicus.”
verses.textLa: Valete. Anno centesimo quadragesimo octavo, Xanthici mensis quintadecima die.

verses.textEn: But the Romans also now sent a letter, having this in it: “Quintus Memmius and Titus Manilius, ambassadors of the Romans, to the people of the Jews: greetings.
verses.textLa: Miserunt autem etiam Romani epistolam, ita se habentem: QUINTUS Memmius, et Titus Manilius legati Romanorum, populo Iudæorum salutem.

verses.textEn: Concerning these things that Lysias, the relative of the king, has conceded to you, we also have conceded.
verses.textLa: De his, quæ Lysias cognatus regis concessit vobis, et nos concessimus.

verses.textEn: But about such things as he judged should be referred to the king, send someone, as soon as you have diligently conferred among yourselves, so that we may make a decree, just as it is agreeable to you. For we are going to Antioch.
verses.textLa: De quibus autem ad regem iudicavit referendum, confestim aliquem mittere, diligentius inter vos conferentes, ut decernamus, sicut congruit vobis: nos enim Antiochiam accedimus.

verses.textEn: And, therefore, make haste to write back, so that we may know whatever your will may be.
verses.textLa: Ideoque festinate rescribere, ut nos quoque sciamus cuius estis voluntatis.

verses.textEn: Farewell. In the one hundred forty-eighth year, on the fifteenth day of the month of Xanthicus.”
verses.textLa: Bene valete. Anno centesimo quadragesimo octavo, quintadecima die mensis Xanthici.

verses.textEn: After these pacts were made, Lysias proceeded on to the king, but the Jews undertook the work of agriculture.
verses.textLa: His factis pactionibus, Lysias pergebat ad regem, Iudæi autem agriculturæ operam dabant.

verses.textEn: However, those who had withdrawn: Timothy, and Apollonius, the son of Gennaeus, along with Hieronymus, and Demophon, and, in addition to these, Nicanor, the governor of Cyprus, would not permit them to live in peace and quiet.
verses.textLa: Sed hi, qui resederant, Timotheus, et Apollonius Gennæi filius, sed et Hieronymus, et Demophon super hos, et Nicanor Cypriarches, non sinebant eos in silentio agere, et quiete.

verses.textEn: Truly, those of Joppa were also perpetrators of very shameful acts. They asked the Jews, who lived among them, to go up into small boats, which they had prepared, with their wives and sons, as if no underlying hostility was between them.
verses.textLa: Ioppitæ vero tale quoddam flagitium perpetrarunt: rogaverunt Iudæos, cum quibus habitabant, ascendere scaphas, quas paraverant, cum uxoribus, et filiis, quasi nullis inimicitiis inter eos subiacentibus.

verses.textEn: And so, according to the common decree of the city, they acquiesced to them, having no suspicions and because there was peace. When they had proceeded out into deep water, they drowned no less than two hundred of them.
verses.textLa: Secundum commune itaque decretum civitatis, et ipsis acquiescentibus, pacisque causa nihil suspectum habentibus: cum in altum processissent, submerserunt non minus ducentos.

verses.textEn: When Judas learned of the cruelty done to the men of his nation, he informed the men who were with him, and, having called upon God, the Just Judge,
verses.textLa: Quam crudelitatem Iudas in suæ gentis homines factam ut cognovit, præcepit viris, qui erant cum ipso: et invocato iusto iudice Deo,

verses.textEn: he went against the executors of his brothers, and he even set the port on fire in the night; he burned the boats, but those who took refuge from the fire, he destroyed with the sword.
verses.textLa: venit adversus interfectores fratrum, et portum quidem noctu succendit, scaphas exussit, eos autem, qui ab igne refugerant, gladio peremit.

verses.textEn: And when he had done these things in this way, he departed, as if he would return again to eradicate all those of Joppa.
verses.textLa: Et cum hæc ita egisset, discessit quasi iterum reversurus, et universos Ioppitas eradicaturus.

verses.textEn: But when he also realized those who were of Jamnia wanted to act in a similar way to the Jews living among them,
verses.textLa: Sed cum cognovisset et eos, qui erant Iamniæ, velle pari modo facere habitantibus secum Iudæis,

verses.textEn: he went against those of Jamnia also by night, and he set the port on fire, along with the ships, so much so that the light of the fire was seen at Jerusalem, two hundred and forty stadia away.
verses.textLa: Iamnitis quoque nocte supervenit, et portum cum navibus succendit: ita ut lumen ignis appareret Ierosolymis a stadiis ducentis quadraginta.
verses.notes: The distance of 240 stadia is about 27.5 miles or about 44 kilometers.

verses.textEn: When they had now gone from there nine stadia, and were making their way toward Timothy, they met in battle with those of Arabia: five thousand men and five hundred horsemen.
verses.textLa: Inde cum iam abiissent novem stadiis, et iter facerent ad Timotheum, commiserunt cum eo Arabes quinque millia viri, et equites quingenti.

verses.textEn: And when a strong fight occurred, and, by the help of God, it ceased favorably, the remainder of the Arabians who were overcome petitioned Judas to give them a pledge, promising to give him pastures and to assist him in other things in the future.
verses.textLa: Cumque pugna valida fieret, et auxilio Dei prospere cessisset, residui Arabes victi, petebant a Iuda dextram sibi dari, promittentes se pascua daturos, et in ceteris profuturos.
verses.notes: Notice, from the way that this passage is worded, that Judas and his army did not fare so well in this battle. They obtained the upper hand after a difficult fight, but they did not completely defeat the Arabs. The battle ceased (cessisset) and the situation at that cessation favored (prospere) Judas, but the Arabs did not turn and flee. It was a marginal victory, not a rout.

verses.textEn: Then Judas, thinking that they truly might be useful in many ways, promised peace. And after receiving the pledge of his right hand, they withdrew to their tents.
verses.textLa: Iudas autem, arbitratus vere in multis eos utiles, promsit pacem: dextrisque acceptis, discessere ad tabernacula sua.

verses.textEn: Then he also assaulted a certain strong city, surrounded with bridges and walls, which was inhabited by a crowd from many different nations, the name of which is Casphin.
verses.textLa: Aggressus est autem et civitatem quamdam firmam pontibus murisque circumseptam, quæ a turbis habitabatur gentium promiscuarum, cui nomen Casphin.

verses.textEn: In truth, those who were inside, trusting in the strength of the walls and in the preparations of rations, acted irresponsibly, and they challenged Judas with evil words and blaspheming, as well as by speaking what is not lawful.
verses.textLa: Hi vero, qui intus erant, confidentes in stabilitate murorum, et apparatu alimoniarum, remissius agebant, maledictis lacessentes Iudam, et blasphemantes, ac loquentes quæ fas non est.

verses.textEn: But Maccabeus rushed fiercely to the walls, calling upon the great Leader of the world, who, without battering rams or machines of war, had thrown down the walls of Jericho in the time of Joshua.
verses.textLa: Machabæus autem, invocato magno mundi Principe, qui sine arietibus, et machinis temporibus Iesu præcipitavit Iericho, irruit ferociter muris:

verses.textEn: And, having captured the city through the will of the Lord, he made a slaughter without number, so much so that an adjoining pool, two stadia in width, was seen to flow with the blood of the slain.
verses.textLa: et capta civitate per Domini voluntatem innumerabiles cædes fecit, ita ut adiacens stagnum stadiorum duorum latitudinis, sanguine interfectorum fluere videretur.

verses.textEn: From there, they withdrew seven hundred and fifty stadia, and they came to Charax, to those Jews who are called Tubianites.
verses.textLa: Inde discesserunt stadia septingenta quinquaginta, et venerunt in Characa ad eos, qui dicuntur Tubianæi, Iudæos:

verses.textEn: And Timothy, indeed, they did not find in those places, for he withdrew before he completed any endeavor, having left behind a very strong garrison in a certain place.
verses.textLa: et Timotheum quidem in illis locis non comprehenderunt, nulloque negotio perfecto regressus est, relicto in quodam loco firmissimo præsidio.

verses.textEn: But Dositheus and Sosipater, who were commanders with Maccabeus, destroyed those who were left behind by Timothy in the stronghold: ten thousand men.
verses.textLa: Dositheus autem, et Sosipater, qui erant duces cum Machabæo, peremerunt a Timotheo relictos in præsidio, decem millia viros.

verses.textEn: And Maccabeus, having positioned six thousand men around him and having divided them into cohorts, went forth against Timothy, who had with him one hundred twenty thousand foot soldiers, and two thousand five hundred horsemen.
verses.textLa: At Machabæus, ordinatis circum se sex millibus, et constitutis per cohortes, adversus Timotheum processit, habentem secum centum viginti millia peditum, equitumque duo millia quingentos.

verses.textEn: But when Timothy learned of the arrival of Judas, he sent ahead the women, and the children, and the remainder of the preparations, into a fortress, which is called Carnion. For it was impregnable and difficult to access because of the narrowness of the places.
verses.textLa: Cognito autem Iudæ adventu, Timotheus præmisit mulieres, et filios, et reliquum apparatum, in præsidium, quod Carnion dicitur: erat enim inexpugnabile, et accessu difficile propter locorum angustias.

verses.textEn: And when the first cohort of Judas had appeared, the enemies were struck with fear by the presence of God, who beholds all things, and they were turned to flight, one over another, to such an extent that they were being knocked over by one another and were being wounded with the strokes of their own swords.
verses.textLa: Cumque cohors Iudæ prima apparuisset, timor hostibus incussus est, ex præsentia Dei, qui universa conspicit, et in fugam versi sunt alius ab alio, ita ut magis a suis deiicerentur, et gladiorum suorum ictibus debilitarentur.

verses.textEn: But Judas pursued them vehemently, punishing the profane and striking down thirty thousand of their men.
verses.textLa: Iudas autem vehementer instabat puniens profanos, et prostravit ex eis triginta millia virorum.

verses.textEn: In truth, Timothy himself fell to the group under Dositheus and Sosipater. And with much begging, he pleaded with them to release him alive, because he held the parents and brothers of many of the Jews, who, at his death, might happen to be mistreated.
verses.textLa: Ipse vero Timotheus incidit in partes Dosithei, et Sosipatris: et multis precibus postulabat ut vivus dimitteretur, eo quod multorum ex Iudæis parentes haberet, ac fratres, quos morte eius decipi eveniret.
verses.notes: This last part sound like a veiled threat by Timothy against those Jews whom his men held under their power.

verses.textEn: And when he had given his faith that he would restore them according to the agreement, they released him unharmed, for the sake of their brothers’ well-being.
verses.textLa: Et cum fidem dedisset restituturum se eos secundum constitutum, illæsum eum dimiserunt propter fratrum salutem.

verses.textEn: Then Judas departed to Carnion, where he slew twenty-five thousand.
verses.textLa: Iudas autem egressus est ad Carnion, interfectis viginti quinque millibus.

verses.textEn: After having put to flight or killed these, he moved his army to Ephron, a fortified city, in which there lived a multitude of diverse peoples. And hardy young men, standing upon the walls, put up a strong fight. Moreover, in this place, there were many machines of war, and equipment for casting darts.
verses.textLa: Post horum fugam, et necem, movit exercitum ad Ephron civitatem munitam, in qua multitudo diversarum gentium habitabat: et robusti iuvenes pro muris consistentes fortiter repugnabant: in hac autem machinæ multæ, et telorum erat apparatus.

verses.textEn: But when they had called upon the Almighty, who with his power breaks the strength of enemies, they seized the city. And they struck down twenty-five thousand of those who were inside.
verses.textLa: Sed cum Omnipotentem invocassent, qui potestate sua vires hostium confringit, ceperunt civitatem: et ex eis, qui intus erant, viginti quinque millia prostraverunt.

verses.textEn: From there, they went to the city of Scythia, which was six hundred stadia away from Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Inde ad civitatem Scytharum abierunt, quæ ab Ierosolymis sexcentis stadiis aberat.

verses.textEn: But the Jews, those who were among the Scythians, testified that they were treated kindly by them, and that, even in the times of unhappiness, they had treated them mildly.
verses.textLa: Contestantibus autem his, qui apud Scythopolitas erant, Iudæis, quod benigne ab eis haberentur, etiam temporibus infelicitatis quod modeste secum egerint:

verses.textEn: They gave thanks to them, exhorting them to be kind to their people, now and at other times. And they went to Jerusalem, as the solemn days of the seven weeks were underway.
verses.textLa: gratias agentes eis, et exhortati etiam de cetero erga genus suum benignos esse, venerunt Ierosolymam die sollemni septimanarum instante.
verses.notes: Or, ‘as the solemn days of the Feast of Weeks were approaching.’

verses.textEn: And, after Pentecost, they marched against Gorgias, the foremost leader over Idumea.
verses.textLa: Et post Pentecosten abierunt contra Gorgiam præpositum Idumææ.

verses.textEn: And he went out with three thousand foot soldiers and four hundred horsemen.
verses.textLa: Exivit autem cum peditibus tribus millibus, et equitibus quadringentis.

verses.textEn: And when they came together, it happened that a few of the Jews were overthrown.
verses.textLa: Quibus congressis, contigit paucos ruere Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: In fact, a certain Dositheus, a horseman of Bacenor, a strong man, took hold of Gorgias. And when he would have captured him alive, a certain horseman of the Thracians rushed upon him and cut off his arm, and so, in this way, Gorgias escaped to Maresa.
verses.textLa: Dositheus vero quidam de Bacenoris eques, vir fortis, Gorgiam tenebat: et, cum vellet illum capere vivum, eques quidam de Thracibus irruit in eum, humerumque eius amputavit: atque ita Gorgias effugit in Maresa.

verses.textEn: But when those who were with Esdris had fought all day and were fatigued, Judas called upon the Lord to be their helper and leader in the battle.
verses.textLa: At illis, qui cum Esdrim erant, diutius pugnantibus et fatigatis, invocavit Iudas Dominum adiutorem, et ducem belli fieri:

verses.textEn: Beginning in the language of the fathers, and loudly extolling hymns, he inspired the soldiers of Gorgias to take flight.
verses.textLa: incipiens voce patria, et cum hymnis clamorem extollens, fugam Gorgiæ militibus incussit.
