verses.textEn: Then Judas, having collected his army, went into the city Adullam. And, when the seventh day came, they purified themselves according to the custom, and they kept the Sabbath in the same place.
verses.textLa: Iudas autem collecto exercitu venit in civitatem Odollam: et, cum septima dies superveniret, secundum consuetudinem purificati, in eodem loco Sabbatum egerunt.

verses.textEn: And the following day, Judas came with his own, in order to take away the bodies of the fallen, and to place them in the sepulchers of their fathers with their ancestors.
verses.textLa: Et sequenti die venit cum suis Iudas, ut corpora prostratorum tolleret, et cum parentibus poneret in sepulchris paternis.

verses.textEn: But they found, under the tunics of the slain, some of the treasures of the idols that were near Jamnia, which were prohibited to Jews by the law. Therefore, it became manifest that it was for this reason that they had been overthrown.
verses.textLa: Invenerunt autem sub tunicis interfectorum de donariis idolorum, quæ apud Iamniam fuerunt, a quibus lex prohibet Iudæos: omnibus ergo manifestum factum est, ob hanc causam eos corruisse.

verses.textEn: And so, they all blessed the just judgment of the Lord, who had made hidden things manifest.
verses.textLa: Omnes itaque benedixerunt iustum iudicium Domini, qui occulta fecerat manifesta.

verses.textEn: So then, turning themselves to prayers, they petitioned him that the offense which had been done would be delivered into oblivion. And truly, the very strong Judas exhorted the people to keep themselves without sin, since they had seen with their own eyes what had happened because of the sins of those who were struck down.
verses.textLa: Atque ita ad preces conversi, rogaverunt ut id, quod factum erat, delictum oblivioni traderetur. At vero fortissimus Iudas hortabatur populum conservare se sine peccato, sub oculis videntes quæ facta sunt pro peccatis eorum, qui prostrati sunt.

verses.textEn: And, calling an assembly, he sent twelve thousand drachmas of silver to Jerusalem, to be offered for a sacrifice for the sins of the dead, thinking well and religiously about the resurrection,
verses.textLa: Et facta collatione, duodecim millia drachmas argenti misit Ierosolymam offerri pro peccatis mortuorum sacrificium, bene et religiose de resurrectione cogitans,

verses.textEn: (for if he had not hoped that those who had fallen would be resurrected, it would have seemed superfluous and vain to pray for the dead,)
verses.textLa: (nisi enim eos, qui ceciderant, resurrecturos speraret, superfluum videretur, et vanum orare pro mortuis)

verses.textEn: and because he considered that those who had fallen asleep with piety had great grace stored up for them.
verses.textLa: et quia considerabat quod hi, qui cum pietate dormitionem acceperant, optimam haberent repositam gratiam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, it is a holy and beneficial thought to pray on behalf of those who have passed away, so that they may be released from sins.
verses.textLa: Sancta ergo, et salubris est cogitatio pro defunctis exorare, ut a peccatis solvantur.

verses.textEn: In the one hundred and forty-ninth year, Judas realized that Antiochus Eupator was coming with a multitude against Judea.
verses.textLa: Anno centesimo quadragesimo nono, cognovit Iudas Antiochum Eupatorem venire cum multitudine adversus Iudæam,

verses.textEn: And with him was Lysias, the procurator, who was in charge of the government, having with him one hundred and ten thousand foot soldiers, five thousand horsemen, and twenty-two elephants, and three hundred swift chariots with curved blades.
verses.textLa: et cum eo Lysiam procuratorem, et præpositum negotiorum, secum habentem peditum centum decem millia, et equitum quinque millia, et elephantos viginti duos, currus cum falcibus trecentos.

verses.textEn: Menelaus also joined himself to them, and with many lies he pleaded with Antiochus, not for the welfare of his country, but hoping that he would be appointed as first ruler.
verses.textLa: Commiscuit autem se illis et Menelaus: et cum multa fallacia deprecabatur Antiochum, non pro patriæ salute, sed sperans se constitui in principatum.

verses.textEn: But the King of kings awakened the mind of Antiochus against the sinner. And when Lysias was suggesting this to be the cause of all the evils, he ordered (as is the custom with them) that he should be apprehended and killed in the same place.
verses.textLa: Sed Rex regum suscitavit animos Antiochi in peccatorem: et suggerente Lysia hunc esse causam omnium malorum, iussit (ut eis est consuetudo) apprehensum in eodem loco necari.

verses.textEn: Now there was, in the same place, a tower of fifty cubits, having a pile of ashes on every side. This had a lookout over a precipice.
verses.textLa: Erat autem in eodem loco turris quinquaginta cubitorum, aggestum undique habens cineris: hæc prospectum habebat in præceps.

verses.textEn: From there, he ordered this sacrilegious one to be thrown down into the ashes, with all propelling him into the afterlife.
verses.textLa: Inde in cinerem deiici iussit sacrilegum, omnibus eum propellentibus ad interitum.

verses.textEn: And by such a law, it turned out that the betrayer of the law, Menelaus, died, not having so much as a burial in the earth.
verses.textLa: Et tali lege prævaricatorem legis contigit mori, nec terræ dari Menelaum.

verses.textEn: And indeed, this satisfied justice, for just as he had committed many offenses toward the altar of God, the fire and ashes of which are holy, so was he condemned to die in ashes.
verses.textLa: Et quidem satis iuste: nam quia multa erga aram Dei delicta commisit, cuius ignis, et cinis erat sanctus: ipse in cineris morte damnatus est.

verses.textEn: But the king, with his mind being unbridled, came to reveal himself as more wicked to the Jews than his father was.
verses.textLa: Sed rex mente effrenatus veniebat, nequiorem se patre suo Iudæis ostensurus.

verses.textEn: When Judas understood this, he instructed the people to call upon the Lord day and night, so that, just as always, now also he would help them.
verses.textLa: Quibus Iudas cognitis, præcepit populo ut die ac nocte Dominum invocarent, quo, sicut semper, et nunc adiuvaret eos:

verses.textEn: Of course, they were afraid to be deprived of their law and their country, and of the holy temple, and also that he might allow the people, who had recently taken a breath for a little while, to be again subdued by blasphemous nations.
verses.textLa: quippe qui lege, et patria, sanctoque templo privari vererentur: ac populum, qui nuper paululum respirasset, ne sineret blasphemis rursus nationibus subdi.

verses.textEn: And so, having together done all these things, and having sought mercy from the Lord with weeping and fasting, lying prostrate on the ground continually for three days, Judas exhorted them to prepare themselves.
verses.textLa: Omnibus itaque simul id facientibus, et petentibus a Domino misericordiam cum fletu, et ieiuniis, per triduum continuum prostratis, hortatus est eos Iudas ut se præpararent.

verses.textEn: In truth, with the elders he decided that, before the king could move his army into Judea and obtain the city, they would go out and commit the outcome of the event to the judgment of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Ipse vero cum senioribus cogitavit prius quam rex admoveret exercitum ad Iudæam, et obtineret civitatem, exire, et Domini iudicio committere exitum rei.

verses.textEn: And so, giving everything to God, the Creator of the world, and having exhorted his own to contend with fortitude and to stand up, even unto death, for the laws, the temple, the city, their country and the citizens: he positioned his army around Modin.
verses.textLa: Dans itaque potestatem omnium Deo mundi Creatori, et exhortatus suos ut fortiter dimicarent, et usque ad mortem pro legibus, templo, civitate, patria, et civibus starent, circa Modin exercitum constituit.

verses.textEn: And having given his own a sign of the victory of God, he attacked the quarters of the king by night, with the strongest chosen young men, and he slew four thousand men in the camp, and the greatest of the elephants, along with those who would have been positioned on them.
verses.textLa: Et dato signo suis Dei victoriæ, iuvenibus fortissimis electis, nocte aggressus aulam regiam, in castris interfecit viros quatuor millia, et maximum elephantorum cum his, qui superpositi fuerant:

verses.textEn: And so, having filled the camp of their enemies with the greatest fear and disturbance, they went away with good success.
verses.textLa: summoque metu, ac perturbatione hostium castra replentes, rebus prospere gestis, abierunt.

verses.textEn: Now this was done at the first light of day, with the Lord assisting and protecting them.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem factum est die illucescente, adiuvante eum Domini protectione.

verses.textEn: But the king, having received a taste of the audacity of the Jews, attempted to take the difficult places by craftiness.
verses.textLa: Sed rex, accepto gustu audaciæ Iudæorum, arte difficultatem locorum tentabat:
verses.notes: The king attempts to win without a major battle, by deceitful negotiations, ‘arte,’ so as to capture the more difficult places without heavy losses. Such is the tactic used by the Antichrist to obtain power over the world (early 25th century).

verses.textEn: And so, he moved his camp to Bethzur, which was a fortified garrison of the Jews. But as he struck, he was put to flight and reduced in number.
verses.textLa: et Bethsuræ, quæ erat Iudæorum præsidium munitum, castra admovebat: sed fugabatur, impingebat, minorabatur.

verses.textEn: Then Judas sent necessities to those who were inside.
verses.textLa: His autem, qui intus erant, Iudas necessaria mittebat.

verses.textEn: But Rhodocus, a certain one from the Jewish army, reported the secrets to the enemies, so he was sought out, apprehended, and imprisoned.
verses.textLa: Enunciavit autem mysteria hostibus Rhodocus quidam de Iudaico exercitu, qui requisitus comprehensus est, et conclusus.

verses.textEn: Again, the king held talks with those who were in Bethzur. He gave his right hand as a pledge, and accepted theirs, and he went away.
verses.textLa: Iterum rex sermonem habuit ad eos, qui erant in Bethsuris: dextram dedit: accepit: abiit.

verses.textEn: He joined battle with Judas; he was overcome. But when he realized that Philip, who had been left out of these events, had rebelled at Antioch, he was in a consternation of mind, and, begging the Jews, and being submissive to them, he swore to all things that seemed just. And, being reconciled, he offered sacrifice, honored the temple, and left gifts.
verses.textLa: Commisit cum Iuda, superatus est. Ut autem cognovit rebellasse Philippum Antiochiæ, qui relictus erat super negotia, mente consternatus Iudæos deprecans, subditusque eis, iurat de omnibus, quibus iustum visum est: et reconciliatus obtulit sacrificium, honoravit templum, et munera posuit:

verses.textEn: He embraced Maccabeus, and he made him commander and leader from Ptolemais all the way to the Gerrenians.
verses.textLa: Machabæum amplexatus est, et fecit eum a Ptolemaide usque ad Gerrenos ducem et principem.

verses.textEn: But when he arrived at Ptolemais, the Ptolemaians considered the conditions of the alliance burdensome, being indignant lest perhaps they might break the pact.
verses.textLa: Ut autem venit Ptolemaidam, graviter ferebant Ptolemenses amicitiæ conventionem, indignantes ne forte fœdus irrumperent.

verses.textEn: Then Lysias went up to the tribunal, and explained the reasons, and calmed the people, and so he returned to Antioch. And this is the way things went concerning the journey and return of the king.
verses.textLa: Tunc ascendit Lysias tribunal, et exposuit rationem, et populum sedavit, regressusque est Antiochiam: et hoc modo regis profectio, et reditus processit.

verses.textEn: But after a time of three years, Judas and those who were with him realized that Demetrius of Seleucus had gone up to strategic places with a very strong multitude and a navy at the port of Tripoli,
verses.textLa: Sed post triennii tempus cognovit Iudas, et qui cum eo erant, Demetrium Seleuci cum multitudine valida, et navibus per portam Tripolis ascendisse ad loca opportuna,

verses.textEn: and had taken hold of the regions opposite Antiochus, and his commander, Lysias.
verses.textLa: et tenuisse regiones adversus Antiochum, et ducem eius Lysiam.

verses.textEn: Now a certain Alcimus, who had been high priest, but who had willfully defiled himself in the time of the co-mingling, considering there to be no means for his safety, nor access to the altar,
verses.textLa: Alcimus autem quidam, qui summus sacerdos fuerat, sed voluntarie coinquinatus est temporibus commistionis, considerans nullo modo sibi esse salutem, neque accessum ad altare,
verses.notes: The time of the co-mingling was when the Gentiles tried to force the Jews to adhere to their pagan sacrifices and to renounce the Jewish Faith.

verses.textEn: went to king Demetrius in the one hundred and fiftieth year, offering to him a crown of gold, and a palm, and beyond these, some branches that seemed to belong to the temple. And, indeed, on that day, he was silent.
verses.textLa: venit ad regem Demetrium centesimo quinquagesimo anno, offerens ei coronam auream, et palmam, super hæc et thallos, qui templi esse videbantur. Et ipsa quidem die siluit.

verses.textEn: But, having met with an opportune time for his madness, he was called to a counsel by Demetrius and asked what things the Jews relied upon and what were their counsels.
verses.textLa: Tempus autem opportunum dementiæ suæ nactus, convocatus a Demetrio ad consilium, et interrogatus quibus rebus et consiliis Iudæi niterentur,
verses.notes: So, about halfway through the Antichrist’s reign (i.e. in the mid 2430’s), an evil leader among the apostate and severely heretical Christians will similarly advise the Antichrist about the faithful Christians who resist him.

verses.textEn: He responded: “Those among the Jews who are called Hasideans, of whom Judas Maccabeus is foremost, nourish wars, and raise seditions, and will not permit the kingdom to be at peace.
verses.textLa: respondit: Ipsi, qui dicuntur Assidæi Iudæorum, quibus præest Iudas Machabæus, bella nutriunt, et seditiones movent, nec patiuntur regnum esse quietum.

verses.textEn: For I also, being cheated out of the glory of my ancestors (but I speak of the high priesthood), have come here,
verses.textLa: Nam et ego defraudatus parentum gloria (dico autem summo sacerdotio) huc veni:

verses.textEn: first, indeed, in faithful service to the king’s interests, but also as an advisor of the citizens. For our entire nation is no less afflicted by their depravity.
verses.textLa: primo quidem utilitatibus regis fidem servans, secundo autem etiam civibus consulens: nam illorum pravitate universum genus nostrum non minime vexatur.

verses.textEn: But I beg you, O king, knowing each of these things, look after both the region and our people, according to your humanity, which is publicly known to all.
verses.textLa: Sed oro his singulis o rex cognitis, et regioni, et generi secundum humanitatem tuam pervulgatam omnibus prospice.

verses.textEn: For, as long as Judas survives, it is impossible for the matter to be at peace.”
verses.textLa: Nam, quamdiu superest Iudas, impossibile est, pacem esse negotiis.
verses.notes: Literally, ‘superest’ means ‘is above,’ in other words, as long as Judas ‘is above ground’ (i.e. alive).

verses.textEn: Then, having spoken such things before them, the rest of the allies, who held themselves to be enemies against Judas, further inflamed Demetrius.
verses.textLa: Talibus autem ab hoc dictis, et ceteri amici, hostiliter se habentes adversus Iudam, inflammaverunt Demetrium.

verses.textEn: And immediately he sent Nicanor, the commander over the elephants, into the first position against Judea,
verses.textLa: Qui statim Nicanorem præpositum elephantorum ducem misit in Iudæam:

verses.textEn: giving him orders to be certain to capture Judas himself, and, truly, to scatter all those who were with him, and to appoint Alcimus as the high priest of the great temple.
verses.textLa: datis mandatis ut ipsum quidem Iudam caperet: eos vero, qui cum illo erant, dispergeret, et constitueret Alcimum maximi templi summum sacerdotem.

verses.textEn: Then the Gentiles, who had fled from Judas away from Judea, mingled themselves in flocks with Nicanor, thinking that the miseries and calamities of the Jews would become the cause of their prosperity.
verses.textLa: Tunc gentes, quæ de Iudæa fugerant Iudam, gregatim se Nicanori miscebant, miserias, et clades Iudæorum prosperitates rerum suarum existimantes.

verses.textEn: And so, when the Jews heard of Nicanor’s arrival and that the nations were assembled, they, sprinkling dirt on their heads, petitioned him who established his people to preserve them in eternity, and who likewise protected his portion by clear signs.
verses.textLa: Audito itaque Iudæi Nicanoris adventu, et conventu nationum, conspersi terra rogabant eum, qui populum suum constituit, ut in æternum custodiret, quique suam portionem signis evidentibus protegit.

verses.textEn: Then, at the command of their leader, they moved promptly from there, and together assembled at the town of Dessau.
verses.textLa: Imperante autem duce, statim inde moverunt, conveneruntque ad castellum Dessau.

verses.textEn: In truth, Simon, the brother of Judas, had joined battle with Nicanor, but he became frightened at the unexpected arrival of the adversaries.
verses.textLa: Simon vero frater Iudæ commiserat cum Nicanore: sed conterritus est repentino adventu adversariorum.

verses.textEn: Even so, Nicanor, hearing of the virtue of the companions of Judas, and the great courage with which they struggled on behalf of their country, was afraid to accomplish judgment by the sword.
verses.textLa: Nicanor tamen, audiens virtutem comitum Iudæ, et animi magnitudinem, quam pro patriæ certaminibus habebant, sanguine iudicium facere metuebat.

verses.textEn: For this reason, he sent ahead Posidonius, and Theodotus, and Matthias, so as to give and receive the pledge of right hands.
verses.textLa: Quam ob rem præmisit Posidonium, et Theodotium, et Matthiam, ut darent dextras atque acciperent.

verses.textEn: And when a council was held all day about this, and the commander had brought it before the multitude, they were all of one opinion to consent to an alliance.
verses.textLa: Et cum diu de his consilium ageretur, et ipse dux ad multitudinem retulisset, omnium una fuit sententia amicitiis annuere.

verses.textEn: And so, they appointed a day, on which they would act among themselves secretly, and seats were brought out and placed for each of them.
verses.textLa: Itaque diem constituerunt, qua secreto inter se agerent: et singulis sellæ prolatæ sunt, et positæ.
verses.notes: They decided to make an alliance, but they were secretly planning to break the alliance on an appointed day.

verses.textEn: But Judas instructed armed men to be in strategic places, lest some kind of malice might unexpectedly spring up from the enemies. And they had an agreeable conference.
verses.textLa: Præcepit autem Iudas armatos esse locis opportunis, ne forte ab hostibus repente mali aliquid oriretur: et congruum colloquium fecerunt.

verses.textEn: Then Nicanor stayed in Jerusalem, and he did no iniquity; he sent away the flocks of the crowds, which had been gathered together.
verses.textLa: Morabatur autem Nicanor Ierosolymis, nihilque inique agebat, gregesque turbarum, quæ congregatæ fuerant, dimisit.

verses.textEn: And Judas always held him dear to the heart, and was favorably inclined toward the man.
verses.textLa: Habebat autem Iudam semper charum ex animo, et erat viro inclinatus.

verses.textEn: And he asked him to consider a wife, and to procreate sons. He got married; he lived quietly, and they all lived in common.
verses.textLa: Rogavitque eum ducere uxorem, filiosque procreare. Nuptias fecit: quiete egit, communiterque vivebant.

verses.textEn: But Alcimus seeing the love that they had for one another, and the agreements, went to Demetrius, and he told him that Nicanor had assented to foreign interests, and that he had chosen Judas, a traitor to the kingdom, as his successor.
verses.textLa: Alcimus autem, videns charitatem illorum ad invicem, et conventiones, venit ad Demetrium, et dicebat, Nicanorem rebus alienis assentire, Iudamque regni insidiatorem successorem sibi destinasse.

verses.textEn: And so the king, being exasperated and provoked by this very wicked accusation, wrote to Nicanor, saying that he was certainly overburdened by the agreement of alliance, and he ordered him nevertheless to send Maccabeus quickly to Antioch in chains.
verses.textLa: Itaque rex exasperatus, et pessimis huius criminationibus irritatus, scripsit Nicanori, dicens, graviter quidem se ferre de amicitiæ conventione, iubere tamen Machabæum citius vinctum mittere Antiochiam.

verses.textEn: When this was known, Nicanor was in consternation, and he took it grievously that he would make void the things that were agreed, having received no injury from the man.
verses.textLa: Quibus cognitis, Nicanor consternabatur, et graviter ferebat, si ea, quæ convenerant, irrita faceret, nihil læsus a viro.

verses.textEn: But, because he was not able to oppose the king, he watched for an opportunity to follow through with the orders.
verses.textLa: Sed, quia regi resistere non poterat, opportunitatem observabat, qua præceptum perficeret.

verses.textEn: But Maccabeus, seeing that Nicanor acted more formally with him, and that, when they met together as usual, he exhibited insolence, understood this austerity not to be from goodness. So, gathering together a few men, he hid himself from Nicanor.
verses.textLa: At Machabæus, videns secum austerius agere Nicanorem, et consuetum occursum ferocius exhibentem, intelligens non ex bono esse austeritatem istam, paucis suorum congregatis, occultavit se a Nicanore.

verses.textEn: But when he realized that he was effectively prevented by the man, he went to the greatest and holiest temple, and he ordered the priests, offering the usual sacrifices, to deliver the man to him.
verses.textLa: Quod cum ille cognovit fortiter se a viro præventum, venit ad maximum et sanctissimum templum: et sacerdotibus solitas hostias offerentibus, iussit sibi tradi virum.

verses.textEn: When these spoke oaths to him that they did not know where he who was being sought was, he extended his hand toward the temple,
verses.textLa: Quibus cum iuramento dicentibus nescire se ubi esset qui quærebatur, extendens manum ad templum,

verses.textEn: and he swore, saying: “Unless you deliver Judas to me in chains, I will reduce this shrine of God to the ground, and I will dig up the altar, and I will consecrate this temple to Liber the father.”
verses.textLa: iuravit, dicens: Nisi Iudam mihi vinctum tradideritis, istud Dei fanum in planitiem deducam, et altare effodiam, et templum hoc Libero patri consecrabo.
verses.notes: Calling the Temple of Jerusalem a ‘fanum’ was somewhat derogatory, as it is the term used more often for pagan shrines than for the holy Temple of Jerusalem.

verses.textEn: And having said this, he departed. But the priests, extending their hands toward heaven, called upon him who had always fought for his people, saying this:
verses.textLa: Et his dictis abiit. Sacerdotes autem protendentes manus in cælum, invocabant eum, qui semper propugnator esset gentis ipsorum, hæc dicentes:

verses.textEn: “O Lord of the universe, who needs nothing, you willed that the temple of your dwelling should be with us.
verses.textLa: Tu Domine universorum, qui nullius indiges, voluisti templum habitationis tuæ fieri in nobis.

verses.textEn: And now, O Lord, Holy of all holies, preserve unpolluted, until eternity, this house, which was recently made clean.”
verses.textLa: Et nunc Sancte sanctorum omnium Domine, conserva in æternum impollutam domum istam, quæ nuper mundata est.

verses.textEn: Then Razias, a certain one of the elders from Jerusalem, was brought before Nicanor; the man was of good reputation, and was one who loved the city. For his affection, he was called the father of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Razias autem quidam de senioribus ab Ierosolymis delatus est Nicanori, vir amator civitatis, et bene audiens: qui pro affectu pater Iudæorum appellabatur.

verses.textEn: This one, for a long time, held on to his purpose of continuing in Judaism, and he was content to hand over body and life, so that he might persevere in it.
verses.textLa: Hic multis temporibus continentiæ propositum tenuit in Iudaismo, corpusque et animam tradere contentus pro perseverantia.

verses.textEn: Then Nicanor, being willing to manifest the hatred that he held for the Jews, sent five hundred soldiers to apprehend him.
verses.textLa: Volens autem Nicanor manifestare odium, quod habebat in Iudæos, misit milites quingentos, ut eum comprehenderent.

verses.textEn: For he thought, if he mistreated him, it would bring great disaster upon the Jews.
verses.textLa: Putabat enim, si illum decepisset, se cladem Iudæis maximam illaturum.

verses.textEn: Now, as the group sought to rush into his house, and to break open the door, and wanting even to bring in fire, as he was about to be apprehended, he struck himself with the sword:
verses.textLa: Turbis autem irruere in domum eius, et ianuam dirumpere, atque ignem admovere cupientibus, cum iam comprehenderetur, gladio se petiit;

verses.textEn: choosing to prefer to die nobly rather than to become subject to sinners, or to suffer unworthy injustices against his birth.
verses.textLa: eligens nobiliter mori potius, quam subditus fieri peccatoribus, et contra natales suos indignis iniuriis agi.
verses.notes: Scripture is infallible. This event actually happened. This man’s action in taking his own life was immoral. But Scripture is not approving of his deed, but merely explaining why he acted in this way. Often, even along with an action that is a mortal sin, there is some good to be found. Also, notice how, by Providence, his death is not an easy or happy death, because Divine Providence does not approve of suicide.

verses.textEn: But, since he had, in haste, not obtained the certitude of a decisive wound, and the crowd was breaking in the doors, he, running boldly to the wall, manfully threw himself down upon the crowd.
verses.textLa: Sed, cum per festinationem non certo ictu plagam dedisset, et turbæ intra ostia irrumperent, recurrens audacter ad murum, præcipitavit semetipsum viriliter in turbas:

verses.textEn: But they quickly provided a place for his fall, so he landed at the middle of the neck.
verses.textLa: quibus velociter locum dantibus casui eius, venit per mediam cervicem:

verses.textEn: And, since he was still breathing, and being inflamed in soul, he rose up, and as his blood flowed down in a great stream, being very gravely wounded, he ran through the crowd.
verses.textLa: et cum adhuc spiraret, accensus animo, surrexit: et cum sanguis eius magno fluxu deflueret, et gravissimis vulneribus esset saucius, cursu turbam pertransiit:

verses.textEn: And standing upon a certain steep rock, and being now almost without blood, grasping his intestines with both hands, he threw himself over the crowd, calling upon the Ruler of life as well as spirit, to restore these to him again. And so he passed away from this life.
verses.textLa: et stans supra quamdam petram præruptam, et iam exsanguis effectus, complexus intestina sua utrisque manibus, proiecit super turbas, invocans Dominatorem vitæ ac spiritus, ut hæc illi iterum redderet: atque ita vita defunctus est.

verses.textEn: But when Nicanor discovered Judas to be in the places of Samaria, he decided to meet him in warfare with all violence, on the Sabbath day.
verses.textLa: Nicanor autem, ut comperit Iudam esse in locis Samariæ, cogitavit cum omni impetu die Sabbati committere bellum.

verses.textEn: In truth, the Jews who followed him out of necessity were saying: “Do not act so fiercely and barbarously, but give honor to the day of sanctification and reverence to him who beholds all things.”
verses.textLa: Iudæis vero, qui illum per necessitatem sequebantur, dicentibus: Ne ita ferociter, et barbare feceris, sed honorem tribue diei sanctificationis, et honora eum, qui universa conspicit:

verses.textEn: That unhappy man asked, “Is there a powerful One in heaven, who commanded the day of the Sabbath to be kept.”
verses.textLa: ille infelix interrogavit, si est potens in cælo, qui imperavit agi diem Sabbatorum.
verses.notes: Some Jews were in the army of Nicanor, out of necessity (by forced conscription), but they were not willing to do battle on the Sabbath. They were willing to attack Judas, but not willing to offend against the holy day. That unhappy man (‘ille infelix’) is Nicanor.

verses.textEn: And they responded to him, “There is the living Lord himself in heaven, the powerful One, who ordered the seventh day to be kept.”
verses.textLa: Et respondentibus illis, Est Dominus vivus ipse in cælo potens, qui iussit agi septimam diem.

verses.textEn: And so he said: “I also am powerful upon the earth, so I command arms to be taken up and the king’s plans to be fulfilled.” Nevertheless, he did not succeed in accomplishing his plan.
verses.textLa: At ille ait: Et ego potens sum super terram, qui impero sumi arma, et negotia regis impleri. Tamen non obtinuit ut consilium perficeret.

verses.textEn: And Nicanor, being certainly lifted up with the greatest arrogance, had decided to establish a public monument of his victory over Judas.
verses.textLa: Et Nicanor quidem cum summa superbia erectus, cogitaverat commune trophæum statuere de Iuda.

verses.textEn: But Maccabeus, as always, trusted with all hope that God would be present to help them.
verses.textLa: Machabæus autem semper confidebat cum omni spe auxilium sibi a Deo affuturum.

verses.textEn: And he exhorted his own not to fear the arrival of the nations, but to keep in mind the assistance they had received before from heaven, and now to hope for a future victory from the Almighty.
verses.textLa: Et hortabatur suos ne formidarent ad adventum nationum, sed in mente haberent adiutoria sibi facta de cælo, et nunc sperarent ab Omnipotente sibi affuturam victoriam.

verses.textEn: And speaking to them from the law and the prophets, reminding them even of the conflicts they had fought before, he made them more willing.
verses.textLa: Et allocutus eos de lege, et prophetis, admonens etiam certamina, quæ fecerant prius, promptiores constituit eos:

verses.textEn: And so, having raised up their courage, at the same time he revealed the deceitful plan of the Gentiles and their betrayal of the oaths.
verses.textLa: et ita animis eorum erectis simul ostendebat Gentium fallaciam, et iuramentorum prævaricationem.

verses.textEn: Then he armed every one of them, not with the weapons of shield and spear, but with the best speeches and exhortations; and he explained to them a dream, worthy to be believed, in which he rejoiced with them all.
verses.textLa: Singulos autem illorum armavit, non clypei, et hastæ munitione, sed sermonibus optimis, et exhortationibus, exposito digno fide somnio, per quod universos lætificavit.

verses.textEn: Now the vision was in this manner: Onias, who had been high priest, a good and kind man, modest in appearance, gentle in manners, and noble in speech, and who from boyhood was trained in the virtues, extending his hands, prayed on behalf of all the people of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Erat autem huiuscemodi visus: Oniam, qui fuerat summus sacerdos, virum bonum et benignum, verecundum visu, modestum moribus, et eloquio decorum, et qui a puero in virtutibus exercitatus sit, manus protendentem, orare pro omni populo Iudæorum:

verses.textEn: After this, there appeared also another man, admirable in age and glory, and with a bearing of great dignity about him.
verses.textLa: Post hoc apparuisse et alium virum ætate, et gloria mirabilem, et magni decoris habitudine circa illum:

verses.textEn: In truth, Onias responded by saying: “This one loves his brothers and the people of Israel. This is he who prays greatly for the people and for all the holy city: Jeremiah, the prophet of God.”
verses.textLa: Respondentem vero Oniam dixisse: Hic est fratrum amator, et populi Israel: hic est, qui multum orat pro populo, et universa sancta civitate, Ieremias propheta Dei.

verses.textEn: Then Jeremiah extended his right hand, and he gave to Judas a sword of gold, saying:
verses.textLa: Extendisse autem Ieremiam dextram, et dedisse Iudæ gladium aureum, dicentem:

verses.textEn: “Receive this holy sword as a gift from God, with it you shall cast down the adversaries of my people Israel.”
verses.textLa: Accipe sanctum gladium munus a Deo, in quo deiicies adversarios populi mei Israel.

verses.textEn: And so, having been exhorted by the very good words of Judas, by which the readiness and courage of the young men were able to be raised and strengthened, they resolved to strive and to contend with fortitude, so that virtue would judge the matter, because the holy city and the temple were in peril.
verses.textLa: Exhortati itaque Iudæ sermonibus bonis valde, de quibus extolli posset impetus, et animi iuvenum confortari, statuerunt dimicare et confligere fortiter: ut virtus de negotiis iudicaret, eo quod civitas sancta, et templum periclitarentur.

verses.textEn: For their concern was less for their wives and sons, and likewise less for their brothers and relatives; in truth, their greatest and first fear was for the sanctity of the temple.
verses.textLa: Erat enim pro uxoribus et filiis, itemque pro fratribus, et cognatis minor solicitudo: maximus vero et primus pro sanctitate timor erat templi.
verses.notes: The word ‘cognatis’ refers to close friends as well as to relatives.

verses.textEn: But those also who were in the city had no small concern for those who had gathered together.
verses.textLa: Sed et eos, qui in civitate erant, non minima solicitudo habebat pro his, qui congressuri erant.

verses.textEn: And, when all now hoped that judgment would soon occur, and when the enemies were near, and the army was set in order, with the beasts and the horsemen positioned in strategic places,
verses.textLa: Et, cum iam omnes sperarent iudicium futurum, hostesque adessent, atque exercitus esset ordinatus, bestiæ, equitesque opportuno in loco compositi,

verses.textEn: Maccabeus, considering the arrival of the multitude, and the various preparations of weapons, and the fierceness of the beasts, extending his hands to heaven, called upon the Lord, who works miracles, who gives victory to those who are worthy, not according to the power of the weapons, but just as it pleases him.
verses.textLa: considerans Machabæus adventum multitudinis, et apparatum varium armorum, et ferocitatem bestiarum, extendens manus in cælum, prodigia facientem Dominum invocavit, qui non secundum armorum potentiam, sed prout ipsi placet, dat dignis victoriam.

verses.textEn: Then, calling out in this way, he said: “You, O Lord, who sent your Angel under Hezekiah, king of Judah, and who killed one hundred and eighty-five thousand from the camp of Sennacherib,
verses.textLa: Dixit autem invocans hoc modo: Tu Domine, qui misisti Angelum tuum sub Ezechia rege Iuda, et interfecisti de castris Sennacherib centum octoginta quinque millia:

verses.textEn: now also, O Ruler of the heavens, send your good Angel before us, who are in fear and trembling at the greatness of your arm,
verses.textLa: et nunc dominator cælorum mitte Angelum tuum bonum ante nos in timore, et tremore magnitudinis brachii tui,

verses.textEn: so that those who approach against your holy people with blasphemy may be afraid.” And in this way, indeed, he concluded his prayer.
verses.textLa: ut metuant qui cum blasphemia veniunt adversus sanctum populum tuum. Et hic quidem ita peroravit.

verses.textEn: But Nicanor, and those who were with him, advanced with trumpets and songs.
verses.textLa: Nicanor autem, et qui cum ipso erant, cum tubis et canticis admovebant.

verses.textEn: In truth, Judas, and those who were with him, calling upon God through prayers, came together against them.
verses.textLa: Iudas vero, et qui cum eo erant, invocato Deo, per orationes congressi sunt:

verses.textEn: Indeed, fighting with their hands, but praying to the Lord with their hearts, they struck down no less than thirty-five thousand, being delighted by the presence of God.
verses.textLa: manu quidem pugnantes, sed Dominum cordibus orantes, prostraverunt non minus trigintaquinque millia, præsentia Dei magnifice delectati.

verses.textEn: And when they had ceased and were returning with gladness, they realized, by his armor, that Nicanor had been slain.
verses.textLa: Cumque cessassent, et cum gaudio redirent, cognoverunt Nicanorem ruisse cum armis suis.

verses.textEn: And so, making a loud noise and inciting a disturbance, they blessed the Almighty Lord in the language of the fathers.
verses.textLa: Facto itaque clamore, et perturbatione excitata, patria voce omnipotentem Dominum benedicebant.

verses.textEn: But Judas, who was prepared throughout all his body and soul to die for his citizens, instructed that Nicanor’s head, and his hand with the arm, should be cut off and carried through to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Præcepit autem Iudas, qui per omnia corpore et animo mori pro civibus paratus erat, caput Nicanoris, et manum cum humero abscissam, Ierosolymam perferri.

verses.textEn: When it arrived, having called together his fellow tribesmen, and the priests to the altar, he summoned those also who were in the stronghold.
verses.textLa: Quo cum pervenisset, convocatis contribulibus, et sacerdotibus ad altare, accersiit et eos, qui in arce erant.

verses.textEn: And he displayed the head of Nicanor, and his nefarious hand, which he had extended against the holy house of Almighty God with magnificent boasting.
verses.textLa: Et ostenso capite Nicanoris, et manu nefaria, quam extendens contra domum sanctam omnipotentis Dei, magnifice gloriatus est.

verses.textEn: He even ordered now that the tongue of the impious Nicanor should be cut up and given in pieces to the birds, but that the hand of this demented man should be suspended opposite the temple.
verses.textLa: Linguam etiam impii Nicanoris præcisam iussit particulatim avibus dari: manum autem dementis contra templum suspendi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they all blessed the Lord of heaven, saying, “Blessed is he who has kept his own place uncontaminated.”
verses.textLa: Omnes igitur cæli benedixerunt Dominum, dicentes: Benedictus, qui locum suum incontaminatum servavit.

verses.textEn: Then he suspended Nicanor’s head at the top of the stronghold, so that it would be an evident and manifest sign of the assistance of God.
verses.textLa: Suspendit autem Nicanoris caput in summa arce, ut evidens esset, et manifestum signum auxilii Dei.

verses.textEn: And so, they all decreed by common counsel in no way to let this day pass without celebration,
verses.textLa: Itaque omnes communi consilio decreverunt nullo modo diem istum absque celebritate præterire:

verses.textEn: but to hold a celebration on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar, which was called in the Syrian language: the day before Mardochias’ day.
verses.textLa: habere autem celebritatem tertiadecima die mensis Adar, quod dicitur voce Syriaca, pridie Mardochæi diei.

verses.textEn: Therefore, these things were accomplished concerning Nicanor, and from that time the city was possessed by the Hebrews. And so, I will bring an end to my narration here.
verses.textLa: Igitur his erga Nicanorem gestis, et ex illis temporibus ab Hebræis civitate possessa, ego quoque in his faciam finem sermonis.

verses.textEn: And, indeed, if I have done well, so as to have made an adequate history, this also is what I wanted. But if it is less than worthy, may it be permitted me.
verses.textLa: Et si quidem bene, et ut historiæ competit, hoc et ipse velim: sin autem minus digne, concedendum est mihi.

verses.textEn: For, just as it is adverse to drink always wine, or always water, so also it is pleasant to use sometimes the one, and sometimes the other. So, if the words were always exact, it would not be pleasing to the readers. Therefore, here it shall be completed.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim vinum semper bibere, aut semper aquam, contrarium est: alternis autem uti, delectabile: ita legentibus si semper exactus sit sermo, non erit gratus. Hic ergo erit consummatus.
verses.notes: The use of excessive precision, or excessive detail, is not fitting for an historical or Scriptural text.
